Accurately separating the flux becomes more difficult than in the observed optical and NIR where the PSF is smaller. We ascertained the effect of the IRAC bands on the fit by re-fitting the spectrum and photometry without IRAC. We found the stellar population parameters to be the same within <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn109.gif\" alt=\"$1\\sigma $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">1\\sigma</script></span></span> and conclude that the IRAC bands do not strongly influence the outcome of the fitting. The current analysis now includes age sensitive absorption features (see below), as well as the new spectroscopic redshift, and therefore we are confident in the stellar population parameters and associated uncertainties determined in this study.</p><p>In Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f5\">5</a>, we find a weak or absent Ca K absorption in the data, whereas the model suggests a stronger absorption line. The observed wavelength of Ca K at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a02.756 is 4780 \u00c5 which overlaps with a strong sky-line at 14793 \u00c5 leading to poor spectral extraction in that region. Thus, the mismatch between the data and model Ca K absorption strength is likely caused by poor data quality in that region. We note that regions affected by strong skylines have larger errors, and will therefore have lower weight in the full spectral fitting</p><p>In addition to the stellar population parameters fit with FAST, we measured the Lick index <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn110.gif\" alt=\"$H{\\delta }_{A}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">H{\\delta }_{A}</script></span></span> (Worthey &amp; Ottaviani <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib75\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib75\">1997</a>) and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn111.gif\" alt=\"${D}_{n}(4000)$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{D}_{n}(4000)</script></span></span> (Balogh et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib2\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib2\">1999</a>) break, which are features shown to be sensitive to age (Kauffmann et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib30\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib30\">2003</a>). With an <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn112.gif\" alt=\"$H{\\delta }_{A}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">H{\\delta }_{A}</script></span></span> measurement from our spectrum, as well as coverage of the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn113.gif\" alt=\"$4000\\;\\mathring{\\rm A} $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">4000\\;\\mathring{\\rm A}</script></span></span> break (as seen by the blue horizontal bars in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f5\">5</a>), we are able to independently verify our model age determination. This independent age verification from the absorption features is important because of inherent degeneracies in fitting the SED. In Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f6\">6</a>, we have plotted <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn114.gif\" alt=\"$H{\\delta }_{A}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">H{\\delta }_{A}</script></span></span> as a function of the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn115.gif\" alt=\"${D}_{n}(4000)$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{D}_{n}(4000)</script></span></span> of our object, as well as a random sample of SDSS galaxies which contain both star-forming and quiescent galaxies.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj522770f6\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj522770f6\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770f6_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 6.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 6.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770f6_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 6.</strong>\u00a0\n<span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn116.gif\" alt=\"$H{\\delta }_{A}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">H{\\delta }_{A}</script></span></span> as a function of <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn117.gif\" alt=\"${D}_{n}(4000)$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{D}_{n}(4000)</script></span></span>. Gray points are a random sample of SDSS galaxies. The orange star is the measurement from the H-band spectroscopy. The solid, colored lines are different Bruzual &amp; Charlot (<a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib11\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib11\">2003</a>) models with different SFH (burst, delayed exponential and constant) with the best-fit values from Table <a class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj522770t1\">1</a> used as inputs. Different benchmark ages are indicated along each track with a triangle (<span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn118.gif\" alt=\"$0.1\\;\\mathrm{Gyr}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">0.1\\;\\mathrm{Gyr}</script></span></span>), circle (<span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn119.gif\" alt=\"$1.0\\;\\mathrm{Gyr}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">1.0\\;\\mathrm{Gyr}</script></span></span>), square (<span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn120.gif\" alt=\"$3.0\\;\\mathrm{Gyr}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">3.0\\;\\mathrm{Gyr}</script></span></span>), and hexagon (<span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn121.gif\" alt=\"$10.0\\;\\mathrm{Gyr}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">10.0\\;\\mathrm{Gyr}</script></span></span>). Marked on the delayed exponential SFH track (the model of choice from FAST), the best-fit age is indicated (red diamond). The close separation reaffirms our age determination.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj522770f6\" href=\"/0004-637X/819/1/74/downloadFigure/figure/apj522770f6\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj522770f6\" href=\"/0004-637X/819/1/74/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj522770f6\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p>Over-plotted in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f6\">6</a> are three different model tracks generated using GALAXEV (Bruzual &amp; Charlot <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib11\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib11\">2003</a>). The best-fit super-solar metallicity of <em>Z</em> = 0.05 from FAST was used in each model track. Two fiducial models (a burst, and constant star formation history) are plotted in blue and magenta to highlight the extremes in the parameter space. A model with a delayed exponential SFH is also plotted in red, using the best-fit parameters from Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj522770t1\">1</a>. The red point corresponds to the age of our best fit using FAST. The separation between the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn122.gif\" alt=\"$H{\\delta }_{A}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">H{\\delta }_{A}</script></span></span> versus <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn123.gif\" alt=\"${D}_{n}(4000)$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{D}_{n}(4000)</script></span></span> determined age and FAST modeled best-fit age is small, confirming the FAST best-fit age in a model independent way. Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f6\">6</a> also shows very little difference in the <em>\u03c4</em> versus delayed-<em>\u03c4</em> models, and that the star formation history is dominated by a population which is consistent with a single burst. From Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f6\">6</a>, we confirm that this galaxy is indeed relatively young, post-starburst, and consistent with being recently quenched.</p></div><h3 id=\"apj522770s3-3\" name=\"apj522770s3-3\">3.3.\u00a0MIPS <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn124.gif\" alt=\"$24\\;\\mu {\\rm{m}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">24\\;\\mu {\\rm{m}}</script></span></span> Photometry</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>As described in Section 5.3 of <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib36\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib36\">M12</a>, there is corresponding MIPS <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn125.gif\" alt=\"$24\\;\\mu {\\rm{m}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">24\\;\\mu {\\rm{m}}</script></span></span> data which was remarked upon. We briefly summarize their findings. They detected observed-frame <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn126.gif\" alt=\"$24\\;\\mu {\\rm{m}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">24\\;\\mu {\\rm{m}}</script></span></span> emission at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn127.gif\" alt=\"$4\\sigma $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">4\\sigma</script></span></span> in the vicinity of the lens system. However, they found the MIPS source to be offset to the south-west by several arcseconds, which suggests that the lens system is not the correct counterpart. Under the possibility that the MIPS detection is coincident with the lens-source system, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib36\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib36\">M12</a> determined an estimate of the sSFR. Since the FWHM of the PSF is <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn128.gif\" alt=\"$5\\buildrel{\\prime\\prime}\\over{.} 5$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">5\\buildrel{\\prime\\prime}\\over{.} 5</script></span></span>, individual sources could not be resolved in MIPS. Photometry was therefore performed in a 7'' aperture which surrounded the entire lens system. For the source and lens, at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn129.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{\\mathrm{phot}}=2.4$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{\\mathrm{phot}}=2.4</script></span></span>, they find <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn130.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\;\\mathrm{sSFR}=-{9.93}_{-0.20}^{+0.20}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\;\\mathrm{sSFR}=-{9.93}_{-0.20}^{+0.20}</script></span></span> which is below the star-forming main sequence for their derived stellar mass at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn131.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{\\mathrm{phot}}=2.4$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{\\mathrm{phot}}=2.4</script></span></span>. Thus, even in the scenario where all of the MIPS emission is associated with the lensed galaxies, they would still be classified as quiescent.</p><p>The new <em>z</em><sub>spec</sub> determination will effect the sSFR found by <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib36\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib36\">M12</a>, which we re-calculate below. We follow the same procedure to find a total un-lensed mass of the source galaxies of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn132.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\;{M}_{*}/{M}_{\\odot }={11.56}_{-0.04}^{+0.08}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\;{M}_{*}/{M}_{\\odot }={11.56}_{-0.04}^{+0.08}</script></span></span>. With the photometry from <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib36\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib36\">M12</a>, and the templates of Dale &amp; Helou (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib21\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib21\">2002</a>), the implied un-lensed SFR is <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn133.gif\" alt=\"${370}_{-83}^{+96}\\;{M}_{\\odot }\\;{\\mathrm{yr}}^{-1}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{370}_{-83}^{+96}\\;{M}_{\\odot }\\;{\\mathrm{yr}}^{-1}</script></span></span>. This yields a <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn134.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\;\\mathrm{sSFR}=-{8.99}_{-0.12}^{+0.12}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\;\\mathrm{sSFR}=-{8.99}_{-0.12}^{+0.12}</script></span></span>. The sSFR of a star-forming main-sequence galaxy is <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn135.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\;\\mathrm{sSFR}\\sim -8.6$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\;\\mathrm{sSFR}\\sim -8.6</script></span></span> for <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn136.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\;{M}_{*}/{M}_{\\odot }=10.59$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\;{M}_{*}/{M}_{\\odot }=10.59</script></span></span> between <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn137.gif\" alt=\"$2.5\\lt z\\lt 3.5$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">2.5\\lt z\\lt 3.5</script></span></span> (Schreiber et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib46\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib46\">2015</a>). This implies that if the MIPS detection is associate with the lensed system, then this galaxy is only 0.3 dex below the star-forming main sequence. We find this implied level of star formation unlikely for two reasons. The first is that the MIPS and NIR sources are offset from one another, and the MIPS detection is not likely associated. The second is our model independent age determination via the strengths of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn138.gif\" alt=\"$H{\\delta }_{A}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">H{\\delta }_{A}</script></span></span> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn139.gif\" alt=\"${D}_{n}(4000)$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{D}_{n}(4000)</script></span></span> (as seen in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f6\">6</a>) which emphasize an older age for the majority of the stars in this galaxy.</p><p>If the MIPS detection were coincident then all star formation would need to be dust-enshrouded, and very recent, so that no young stars are visible outside the birth-clouds. An alternative explanation is that the lens-source system could host an AGN, but we do not see emission lines in the near-IR or optical. Additionally, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib36\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib36\">M12</a> looked for X-ray and radio detections in <em>XMM-Newton</em> and the Very Large Array observations of the COSMOS field and found no detection in the vicinity of the system.</p></div><h3 id=\"apj522770s3-4\" name=\"apj522770s3-4\">3.4.\u00a0Stellar Velocity Dispersion</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>The presence of strong absorption features provide us with the means to study the kinematics of this galaxy, and determine a stellar velocity dispersion. With this measurement, we are able to calculate the dynamical mass and place strong constraints on the baryonic contribution to the total mass budget. Although random errors on broadband photometry can be quite low with state-of-the-art instruments, systematic uncertainties in mass determinations are difficult to estimate accurately (Conroy et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib19\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib19\">2009</a>). Thus, velocity dispersions are key for placing upper limits on the total mass of the system, and hence validating stellar mass estimates.</p><p>A stellar velocity dispersion was estimated using Penalized Pixel-Fitting (pPXF; Cappellari &amp; Emsellem <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib16\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib16\">2004</a>). The spectrum was first resampled onto a logarithmic wavelength scale without interpolation, but with the masking of bad pixels. Template mismatch was accounted for by simultaneously fitting the continuum of the best-fit Bruzual &amp; Charlot (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib11\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib11\">2003</a>) template with an additive polynomial, following the same analysis presented in Appendix 3 of van de Sande et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib60\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib60\">2013</a>).</p><p>The effect of template choice can greatly affect the fitted velocity dispersion. We investigated the effect of template choice on the best-fit stellar velocity dispersion, in a similar manner to van de Sande et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib60\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib60\">2013</a>). We fit the spectrum and photometry using FAST with a range of templates for a grid of fixed metallicity and ages. The allowable metallicities were <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn140.gif\" alt=\"$Z=0.004$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">Z=0.004</script></span></span> (super sub-solar), 0.008 (sub-solar), 0.02 (solar) and 0.05 (super-solar). The age range considered was <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn141.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\;\\mathrm{Age}\\;{\\mathrm{years}}^{-1}\\quad =$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\;\\mathrm{Age}\\;{\\mathrm{years}}^{-1}\\quad =</script></span></span> 8.0\u20139.5 in increments of 0.1 dex. We increased the resolution of the age grid to 0.05 dex between <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn142.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\;\\mathrm{Age}\\;{\\mathrm{years}}^{-1}\\quad =$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\;\\mathrm{Age}\\;{\\mathrm{years}}^{-1}\\quad =</script></span></span> 8.6\u20138.9, as we found in previous fitting iterations that the FAST estimated <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn143.gif\" alt=\"$1\\sigma $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">1\\sigma</script></span></span>-error was smaller than 0.1 dex.</p><p>In Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f7\">7</a>, we show the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn144.gif\" alt=\"${\\chi }_{\\mathrm{red}}^{2}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\chi }_{\\mathrm{red}}^{2}</script></span></span> from FAST as a function of the best-fit pPXF stellar velocity dispersion (corrected for template, <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn145.gif\" alt=\"$\\sigma =89\\;\\mathrm{km}\\;{{\\rm{s}}}^{-1}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\sigma =89\\;\\mathrm{km}\\;{{\\rm{s}}}^{-1}</script></span></span>, and instrument, <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn146.gif\" alt=\"$\\sigma =25\\;\\mathrm{km}\\;{{\\rm{s}}}^{-1}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\sigma =25\\;\\mathrm{km}\\;{{\\rm{s}}}^{-1}</script></span></span>, resolution). Using Monte-Carlo simulated errors, we determined 1 and 2 sigma limits on the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn147.gif\" alt=\"${\\chi }_{\\mathrm{red}}^{2}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\chi }_{\\mathrm{red}}^{2}</script></span></span> value of the best-fit FAST model (horizontal black dashed lines in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f7\">7</a>). Points that fall below this line are statistically indistinguishable. We find a very narrow range of statistically indistinguishable templates, concluding that our error will be dominated by the formal errors of the fit, and not the template choice.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj522770f7\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj522770f7\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770f7_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 7.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 7.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770f7_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 7.</strong>\u00a0The pPXF best-fit stellar velocity dispersion plotted against the <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn148.gif\" alt=\"${\\chi }_{\\mathrm{red}}^{2}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\chi }_{\\mathrm{red}}^{2}</script></span></span> output from FAST fitting both the spectrum and the photometry. Each point represents a different age (from <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn149.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\;\\mathrm{Age}\\;{\\mathrm{years}}^{-1}\\quad =$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\;\\mathrm{Age}\\;{\\mathrm{years}}^{-1}\\quad =</script></span></span> 8.0\u20139.5), and each colored \"track\" a different metallicity. The horizontal dashed black lines are the <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn150.gif\" alt=\"$1\\sigma $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">1\\sigma</script></span></span> and <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn151.gif\" alt=\"$2\\sigma $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">2\\sigma</script></span></span> upper bounds from the Monte Carlo modeling of the best-fit template at <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn152.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\;\\mathrm{Age}\\;{\\mathrm{years}}^{-1}=8.75$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\;\\mathrm{Age}\\;{\\mathrm{years}}^{-1}=8.75</script></span></span>. Points below these lines indicate templates that are statistically indistinguishable from each other. There are only three of these points, and they result in a stable stellar velocity dispersion implying that template choice is not the dominant source of uncertainty.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj522770f7\" href=\"/0004-637X/819/1/74/downloadFigure/figure/apj522770f7\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj522770f7\" href=\"/0004-637X/819/1/74/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj522770f7\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p>Accounting for instrumental and template resolution, as well as a rectangular aperture and seeing (see van de Sande et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib60\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib60\">2013</a>), we find a best-fit pPXF stellar velocity dispersion of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn153.gif\" alt=\"$\\sigma =187\\pm 43\\;\\mathrm{km}\\;{{\\rm{s}}}^{-1}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\sigma =187\\pm 43\\;\\mathrm{km}\\;{{\\rm{s}}}^{-1}</script></span></span> (the error is the 68% confidence limits from the Monte-Carlo simulations).</p><p>From the assumption that the galaxy is virialized, we can determine the dynamical mass as follows:</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj522770eqn2\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770eqn2.gif\" alt=\"Equation (2)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{M}_{\\mathrm{dyn}}=\\displaystyle \\frac{\\beta (n){\\sigma }_{{\\rm{e}}}^{2}{r}_{{\\rm{e}}}}{G}.\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t2\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>Here <em>G</em> is the gravitational constant, and <em>\u03b2</em> is an expression as a function of the S\u00e9rsic index, <em>n</em>, from Cappellari et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib15\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib15\">2006</a>, their Equation (20)):</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj522770eqn3\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770eqn3.gif\" alt=\"Equation (3)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&\\beta (n)=8.87-0.831n+0.0241{n}^{2}.\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t3\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>\n</p><p>With <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn154.gif\" alt=\"${r}_{{\\rm{e}}}={0.86}_{-0.14}^{+0.19}\\;\\mathrm{kpc}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{r}_{{\\rm{e}}}={0.86}_{-0.14}^{+0.19}\\;\\mathrm{kpc}</script></span></span> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn155.gif\" alt=\"${3.50}_{-0.60}^{+0.68}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{3.50}_{-0.60}^{+0.68}</script></span></span> from Muzzin et al. (2016, in preparation), the dynamical mass is <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn156.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\;{M}_{\\mathrm{dyn}}/{M}_{\\odot }\\quad ={10.65}_{-0.23}^{+0.18}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\;{M}_{\\mathrm{dyn}}/{M}_{\\odot }\\quad ={10.65}_{-0.23}^{+0.18}</script></span></span> which is quite similar to, but slightly above the derived stellar mass of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn157.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\;{M}_{*}/{M}_{\\odot }={10.59}_{-0.05}^{+0.04}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\;{M}_{*}/{M}_{\\odot }={10.59}_{-0.05}^{+0.04}</script></span></span>.</p><p>Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f8\">8</a> shows <em>r</em><sub>e</sub> as a function of stellar and dynamical mass for high and low-<em>z</em> galaxies with measured stellar velocity dispersions. Also included in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f8\">8</a> is the quiescent galaxy mass\u2013size relation for <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn158.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 0$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 0</script></span></span> (dashed black line). In both stellar and dynamical mass we see that our galaxy is smaller than <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn159.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 0$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 0</script></span></span> galaxies at equivalent mass, and consistent with the higher-redshift quiescent population. This galaxy is indeed compact, which is well established for quiescent galaxies at these redshifts (see Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj522770s1\">1</a> and references therein).</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj522770f8\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj522770f8\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770f8_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 8.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 8.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770f8_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 8.</strong>\u00a0Left: the dynamical mass (<em>M</em><sub>dyn</sub>) vs. <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn160.gif\" alt=\"${r}_{{\\rm{e}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{r}_{{\\rm{e}}}</script></span></span> of the object of this study (orange star) plotted along side other high-redshift objects compiled from van de Sande et al. (<a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib58\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib58\">2015</a>) where the colored symbols follow the same conventions as the legend in Figure <a href=\"#apj522770f2\">2</a>. The dashed black line is the parameterized mass\u2013size relation of SDSS <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn161.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 0$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 0</script></span></span> quiescent galaxies, with the best-fit parameters from van de Sande et al. (<a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib59\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib59\">2011</a>). Right: the same as the left plot, but with stellar mass instead of dynamical mass. In both instances, our object falls below the mass\u2013size relation of <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn162.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 0$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 0</script></span></span> quiescent galaxies confirming compactness out to lower masses at high redshift.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj522770f8\" href=\"/0004-637X/819/1/74/downloadFigure/figure/apj522770f8\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj522770f8\" href=\"/0004-637X/819/1/74/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj522770f8\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p>Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f9\">9</a> shows the comparison between the FAST determined <em>M</em><sub>*</sub>, and the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn163.gif\" alt=\"${M}_{\\mathrm{dyn}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{M}_{\\mathrm{dyn}}</script></span></span>. The black dashed line in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f9\">9</a> is unity\u2014above this line is an \"unphysical\" regime where the stellar mass exceeds the dynamical mass. From this figure, we see that the implied dark matter fraction appears to be very low, at least in the central regions of the galaxy where the bulk of the light is found (Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f8\">8</a>). However the error bars are large, and a dark matter fraction of 50% is also consistent with the data, therefore a definitive conclusion can not be drawn.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj522770f9\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj522770f9\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770f9_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 9.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 9.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770f9_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 9.</strong>\u00a0Dynamical (<em>M</em><sub>dyn</sub>) vs. the stellar (<span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn164.gif\" alt=\"${M}_{*}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{M}_{*}</script></span></span>) mass of the object of this study (orange star) plotted along side other high-redshift objects compiled from van de Sande et al. (<a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib58\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib58\">2015</a>) where the colored symbols follow the same conventions as the legend in Figure <a href=\"#apj522770f2\">2</a>. The high-<em>z</em> objects are mass and color selected. SDSS galaxies are the gray points (which have been color selected with the same UVJ selection as found in Figure <a href=\"#apj522770f2\">2</a>), and the dashed black line is unity. For our object, the stellar mass and dynamical mass agree well.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj522770f9\" href=\"/0004-637X/819/1/74/downloadFigure/figure/apj522770f9\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj522770f9\" href=\"/0004-637X/819/1/74/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj522770f9\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p>In Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f10\">10</a>, we directly compare the total-to-stellar mass ratio (and thus, the dark matter fraction) as a function of redshift, where the mass fraction approaches unity (also seen in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f9\">9</a>). This figure contains the same literature compilation of high-<em>z</em> quiescent galaxies with velocity dispersion measurements as found in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f2\">2</a>. Of the known objects with a velocity dispersion, ours is at the highest redshift, and one of the lowest total-to-stellar mass ratios. There is also a weak trend, with quiescent galaxies becoming increasingly baryon dominated with redshift. This trend was also noted by van de Sande et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib60\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib60\">2013</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib58\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib58\">2015</a>) whose sample extended out to <em>z</em> = 2.3, however between <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00 and <em>z</em> = 1.6, Belli et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib3\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib3\">2014a</a>) found no statistically significant evolution. This may suggest a rapid evolution between redshift <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn165.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 3$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 3</script></span></span> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn166.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 1.6$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 1.6</script></span></span>. To test this, we compare the average total-to-stellar mass ratio of the SDSS sample to galaxies above redshift <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn167.gif\" alt=\"$z\\gt 1.6$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\gt 1.6</script></span></span>. In Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f10\">10</a>, we have indicated the SDSS median total-to-stellar mass ratio as gray circle. The average for galaxies above <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn168.gif\" alt=\"$z\\gt 1.6$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\gt 1.6</script></span></span> is indicated by the red symbol with the 68% confidence interval. From Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f10\">10</a>, we see that galaxies at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn169.gif\" alt=\"$z\\gt 1.6$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\gt 1.6</script></span></span> do have a lower total-to-stellar mass ratio consistent with the findings of van de Sande et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib60\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib60\">2013</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib58\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib58\">2015</a>), however, the average value for the SDSS galaxies and those above <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn170.gif\" alt=\"$z\\gt 1.6$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\gt 1.6</script></span></span> are not statistically different (i.e., they fall within the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn171.gif\" alt=\"$2.5\\sigma $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">2.5\\sigma</script></span></span> uncertainty).</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj522770f10\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj522770f10\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770f10_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 10.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 10.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770f10_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 10.</strong>\u00a0Redshift vs. ratio of dynamical to stellar masses of the color-selected sample compiled by van de Sande et al. (<a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib58\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib58\">2015</a>), and our object. Gray points are SDSS galaxies following the same color selection. The colored symbols follow the same conventions as the legend in Figure <a href=\"#apj522770f2\">2</a>. The gray circle is the average total-to-stellar mass ratio for SDSS galaxies. We note that the 68% confidence limit for the average total-to-stellar mass ratio for the SDSS galaxies is smaller than the gray symbol. The large red circle is the average total-to-stellar mass ratio for galaxies at <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn172.gif\" alt=\"$z\\gt 1.6$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\gt 1.6</script></span></span> with 68% confidence limits. Our object is the highest redshift for which a dispersion has been measured.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj522770f10\" href=\"/0004-637X/819/1/74/downloadFigure/figure/apj522770f10\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj522770f10\" href=\"/0004-637X/819/1/74/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj522770f10\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure></div><h3 id=\"apj522770s3-5\" name=\"apj522770s3-5\">3.5.\u00a0Mass Fundamental Plane</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>Given a stellar mass, a precisely determined <em>r</em><sub>e</sub>, and our stellar velocity dispersion measurement, we are able to tentatively explore the MFP to <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn173.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 3$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 3</script></span></span>, as well as lower masses. The most salient difference between the FP and MFP with regards to evolution with redshift is the zero-point. Although the zero-point of the traditional luminosity FP is shown to evolve with redshift (e.g., van Dokkum &amp; Franx <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib64\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib64\">1996</a>; van Dokkum et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib65\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib65\">1998</a>; Treu et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib55\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib55\">1999</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib54\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib54\">2001</a>), the MFP does not (Bolton et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib8\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib8\">2008</a>; Holden et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib27\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib27\">2010</a>; Bezanson et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib6\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib6\">2013</a>). The evolution of the zero-point of the FP can be used to investigate the luminosity evolution of quiescent galaxies, whereas the zero-point evolution in the MFP can be used to investigate the corresponding structural and dynamical evolution (Bezanson et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib6\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib6\">2013</a>).</p><p>Strikingly, Bezanson et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib6\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib6\">2013</a>) established that the zero-point of the MFP does not evolve significantly with redshift, in spite of evolution in the structure and size of quiescent galaxies since <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn174.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 2</script></span></span> (see Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj522770s1\">1</a> and references therein). One outstanding question is whether this trend holds to higher redshifts and lower mass. With this data, we are able to explore both issues simultaneously.</p><p>In Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f11\">11</a> we compare our measurement to galaxies at the highest available redshifts which have velocity dispersions. We applied a redshift cut to the literature compilation of van de Sande et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib58\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib58\">2015</a>) of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn175.gif\" alt=\"$z\\gt 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\gt 2</script></span></span>, which left only 5 galaxies (where the highest spectroscopic redshift is <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn176.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{\\mathrm{spec}}=2.636$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{\\mathrm{spec}}=2.636</script></span></span>) for comparison. Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f11\">11</a> shows that, within measurement uncertainty, our galaxy lies on the same MFP as galaxies at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn177.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 2</script></span></span>. This coherence between <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn178.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 2</script></span></span> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn179.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 3$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 3</script></span></span> suggests that the MFP evolves very little between these epochs. Further data at these redshifts are required for a definitive conclusion.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj522770f11\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj522770f11\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770f11_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 11.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 11.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770f11_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 11.</strong>\u00a0The mass fundamental plane for galaxies at redshift <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn180.gif\" alt=\"$z\\gt 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\gt 2</script></span></span>. Symbols are as per the previous figures. The black dashed line is the best-fit mass FP between <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn181.gif\" alt=\"$1.5\\lt z\\lt 2.2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">1.5\\lt z\\lt 2.2</script></span></span> from Bezanson et al. (<a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib6\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib6\">2013</a>). Our galaxy is within the variance of the galaxies at <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn182.gif\" alt=\"$z\\gt 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\gt 2</script></span></span> around the mass fundamental plane suggesting it is in place at lower masses.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj522770f11\" href=\"/0004-637X/819/1/74/downloadFigure/figure/apj522770f11\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj522770f11\" href=\"/0004-637X/819/1/74/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj522770f11\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure></div></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apj522770s4\" name=\"apj522770s4\">4.\u00a0DISCUSSION AND CONCLUSIONS</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>We have obtained an X-Shooter VLT spectrum of the multiply imaged lensed galaxy COSMOS 0050+4901 found serendipitously in the UltraVISTA field. The lensing of this quiescent galaxy was fortunate, providing a detailed, \"sneak-peak\" at the universe during an exciting time. In order to obtain a spectrum with equivalent S/N, without the magnifying effects of gravitational-lensing, 215 hr of integration time on a 10 m class telescope would have been required. The existence of only a handful of gravitationally lensed, quiescent galaxies (Auger et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib1\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib1\">2011</a>; Geier et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib26\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib26\">2013</a>; Newman et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib39\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib39\">2015</a>) highlights the rarity of these objects, and the opportunity they provide to study the high-<em>z</em>, intermediate-mass mass universe preceding the era of <em>JWST</em>.</p><p>At <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn183.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{\\mathrm{spec}}=2.756\\pm 0.001$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{\\mathrm{spec}}=2.756\\pm 0.001</script></span></span>, COSMOS 0050+4901 is one of the highest-redshift quiescent galaxies with a spectroscopic redshift, as well as the highest-redshift galaxy with a measured velocity dispersion (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn184.gif\" alt=\"$\\sigma =187\\pm 43\\;\\mathrm{km}\\;{{\\rm{s}}}^{-1}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\sigma =187\\pm 43\\;\\mathrm{km}\\;{{\\rm{s}}}^{-1}</script></span></span>). With this spectrum we have detected a suite of Balmer lines (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn185.gif\" alt=\"$H\\gamma $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">H\\gamma</script></span></span>, <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn186.gif\" alt=\"$H\\delta $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">H\\delta</script></span></span>), and the CaH and K absorption lines in the observed H band (Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f5\">5</a>). The detection of multiple absorption lines provides tight constraints on <em>z</em><sub>spec</sub>, and is additionally indicative of the presence of older stellar populations. Within the wavelength covered by the spectrum, we find no evidence of emission lines. With our spectrum, the understanding of the stellar populations of this galaxy change from an older (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn187.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\;\\mathrm{Age}\\;{\\mathrm{years}}^{-1}={9.0}_{-0.2}^{+0.2}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\;\\mathrm{Age}\\;{\\mathrm{years}}^{-1}={9.0}_{-0.2}^{+0.2}</script></span></span>), massive (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn188.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\;{M}_{*}/{M}_{\\odot }\\quad ={10.82}_{-0.07}^{+0.05}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\;{M}_{*}/{M}_{\\odot }\\quad ={10.82}_{-0.07}^{+0.05}</script></span></span>), dusty (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn189.gif\" alt=\"${A}_{V}={0.9}_{-0.6}^{+0.2}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{A}_{V}={0.9}_{-0.6}^{+0.2}</script></span></span>) galaxy (as found by <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib36\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib36\">M12</a>) to a younger (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn190.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\;\\mathrm{Age}\\;{\\mathrm{years}}^{-1}={8.75}_{-0.07}^{+0.07}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\;\\mathrm{Age}\\;{\\mathrm{years}}^{-1}={8.75}_{-0.07}^{+0.07}</script></span></span>), post-starburst galaxy of intermediate mass (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn191.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\;{M}_{*}/{M}_{\\odot }={10.59}_{-0.05}^{+0.04}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\;{M}_{*}/{M}_{\\odot }={10.59}_{-0.05}^{+0.04}</script></span></span>).</p><p>This new age determination is supported by spectral diagnostics such as the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn192.gif\" alt=\"${D}_{{\\rm{n}}}(4000)$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{D}_{{\\rm{n}}}(4000)</script></span></span> (Balogh et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib2\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib2\">1999</a>) and the Lick index <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn193.gif\" alt=\"$H{\\delta }_{A}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">H{\\delta }_{A}</script></span></span> (Worthey &amp; Ottaviani <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib75\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib75\">1997</a>), which have been shown to be sensitive to age (Kauffmann et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib30\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib30\">2003</a>). In Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f6\">6</a>, we show how the aforementioned spectral diagnostics reaffirm the younger age determination of this study in a model independent way. Equipped with this best-fit age, the rest-frame optical colors (Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f2\">2</a>), and the SFR from stellar population modeling (Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f4\">4</a>), we confirm that intermediate-mass galaxies that halt in situ star formation are in place by <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn194.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 3$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 3</script></span></span>.</p><p>In addition to the brightening effects of the magnification, the magnifying effects also increase spatial resolution. With this increase in resolution, accurate structural parameters are determined. Muzzin et al. (2016, in preparation) modeled the gravitationally lensed system and determined the magnification, as well as the surface brightness profile, measuring a S\u00e9rsic index of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn195.gif\" alt=\"${3.50}_{-0.60}^{+0.68}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{3.50}_{-0.60}^{+0.68}</script></span></span> and an <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn196.gif\" alt=\"${r}_{{\\rm{e}}}={0.86}_{-0.14}^{+0.19}\\;\\mathrm{kpc}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{r}_{{\\rm{e}}}={0.86}_{-0.14}^{+0.19}\\;\\mathrm{kpc}</script></span></span>. The right-hand panel of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f8\">8</a> shows the precise <em>r</em><sub>e</sub> measurement of Muzzin et al. (2016, in preparation) as a function of the stellar mass. Over-plotted for comparison are a local, and high-redshift sample. Like the high-redshift sample, our object falls below the local size-mass relation (Shen et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib48\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib48\">2003</a>). We confirm, with a high degree of precision, that this galaxy is compact, which is consistent with what is seen for quiescent galaxies at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn197.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 2</script></span></span> (e.g., Daddi et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib20\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib20\">2005</a>; Trujillo et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib56\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib56\">2006</a>; Zirm et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib77\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib77\">2007</a>; van Dokkum et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib66\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib66\">2008</a>; Szomoru et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib52\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib52\">2012</a>).</p><p>Spectroscopy also allows for a kinematic determination of the mass. The measurement of a dynamical mass is important, as it provides a direct, kinematic method of probing the total matter content of a galaxy, without the uncertainties and prior assumptions associated with parameters such as distance measurement, IMF, and dust content (i.e Conroy et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib19\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib19\">2009</a> places the uncertainty associated with stellar mass estimates to be <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn198.gif\" alt=\"$0.6\\;\\mathrm{dex}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">0.6\\;\\mathrm{dex}</script></span></span> at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn199.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 2</script></span></span>).
