This coherence between <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn178.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 2</script></span></span> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn179.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 3$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 3</script></span></span> suggests that the MFP evolves very little between these epochs. Further data at these redshifts are required for a definitive conclusion.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj522770f11\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj522770f11\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770f11_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 11.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 11.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770f11_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 11.</strong>\u00a0The mass fundamental plane for galaxies at redshift <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn180.gif\" alt=\"$z\\gt 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\gt 2</script></span></span>. Symbols are as per the previous figures. The black dashed line is the best-fit mass FP between <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn181.gif\" alt=\"$1.5\\lt z\\lt 2.2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">1.5\\lt z\\lt 2.2</script></span></span> from Bezanson et al. (<a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib6\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib6\">2013</a>). Our galaxy is within the variance of the galaxies at <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn182.gif\" alt=\"$z\\gt 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\gt 2</script></span></span> around the mass fundamental plane suggesting it is in place at lower masses.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj522770f11\" href=\"/0004-637X/819/1/74/downloadFigure/figure/apj522770f11\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj522770f11\" href=\"/0004-637X/819/1/74/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj522770f11\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure></div></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apj522770s4\" name=\"apj522770s4\">4.\u00a0DISCUSSION AND CONCLUSIONS</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>We have obtained an X-Shooter VLT spectrum of the multiply imaged lensed galaxy COSMOS 0050+4901 found serendipitously in the UltraVISTA field. The lensing of this quiescent galaxy was fortunate, providing a detailed, \"sneak-peak\" at the universe during an exciting time. In order to obtain a spectrum with equivalent S/N, without the magnifying effects of gravitational-lensing, 215 hr of integration time on a 10 m class telescope would have been required. The existence of only a handful of gravitationally lensed, quiescent galaxies (Auger et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib1\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib1\">2011</a>; Geier et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib26\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib26\">2013</a>; Newman et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib39\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib39\">2015</a>) highlights the rarity of these objects, and the opportunity they provide to study the high-<em>z</em>, intermediate-mass mass universe preceding the era of <em>JWST</em>.</p><p>At <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn183.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{\\mathrm{spec}}=2.756\\pm 0.001$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{\\mathrm{spec}}=2.756\\pm 0.001</script></span></span>, COSMOS 0050+4901 is one of the highest-redshift quiescent galaxies with a spectroscopic redshift, as well as the highest-redshift galaxy with a measured velocity dispersion (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn184.gif\" alt=\"$\\sigma =187\\pm 43\\;\\mathrm{km}\\;{{\\rm{s}}}^{-1}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\sigma =187\\pm 43\\;\\mathrm{km}\\;{{\\rm{s}}}^{-1}</script></span></span>). With this spectrum we have detected a suite of Balmer lines (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn185.gif\" alt=\"$H\\gamma $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">H\\gamma</script></span></span>, <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn186.gif\" alt=\"$H\\delta $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">H\\delta</script></span></span>), and the CaH and K absorption lines in the observed H band (Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f5\">5</a>). The detection of multiple absorption lines provides tight constraints on <em>z</em><sub>spec</sub>, and is additionally indicative of the presence of older stellar populations. Within the wavelength covered by the spectrum, we find no evidence of emission lines. With our spectrum, the understanding of the stellar populations of this galaxy change from an older (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn187.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\;\\mathrm{Age}\\;{\\mathrm{years}}^{-1}={9.0}_{-0.2}^{+0.2}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\;\\mathrm{Age}\\;{\\mathrm{years}}^{-1}={9.0}_{-0.2}^{+0.2}</script></span></span>), massive (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn188.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\;{M}_{*}/{M}_{\\odot }\\quad ={10.82}_{-0.07}^{+0.05}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\;{M}_{*}/{M}_{\\odot }\\quad ={10.82}_{-0.07}^{+0.05}</script></span></span>), dusty (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn189.gif\" alt=\"${A}_{V}={0.9}_{-0.6}^{+0.2}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{A}_{V}={0.9}_{-0.6}^{+0.2}</script></span></span>) galaxy (as found by <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib36\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib36\">M12</a>) to a younger (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn190.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\;\\mathrm{Age}\\;{\\mathrm{years}}^{-1}={8.75}_{-0.07}^{+0.07}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\;\\mathrm{Age}\\;{\\mathrm{years}}^{-1}={8.75}_{-0.07}^{+0.07}</script></span></span>), post-starburst galaxy of intermediate mass (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn191.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\;{M}_{*}/{M}_{\\odot }={10.59}_{-0.05}^{+0.04}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\;{M}_{*}/{M}_{\\odot }={10.59}_{-0.05}^{+0.04}</script></span></span>).</p><p>This new age determination is supported by spectral diagnostics such as the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn192.gif\" alt=\"${D}_{{\\rm{n}}}(4000)$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{D}_{{\\rm{n}}}(4000)</script></span></span> (Balogh et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib2\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib2\">1999</a>) and the Lick index <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn193.gif\" alt=\"$H{\\delta }_{A}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">H{\\delta }_{A}</script></span></span> (Worthey &amp; Ottaviani <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib75\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib75\">1997</a>), which have been shown to be sensitive to age (Kauffmann et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib30\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib30\">2003</a>). In Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f6\">6</a>, we show how the aforementioned spectral diagnostics reaffirm the younger age determination of this study in a model independent way. Equipped with this best-fit age, the rest-frame optical colors (Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f2\">2</a>), and the SFR from stellar population modeling (Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f4\">4</a>), we confirm that intermediate-mass galaxies that halt in situ star formation are in place by <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn194.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 3$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 3</script></span></span>.</p><p>In addition to the brightening effects of the magnification, the magnifying effects also increase spatial resolution. With this increase in resolution, accurate structural parameters are determined. Muzzin et al. (2016, in preparation) modeled the gravitationally lensed system and determined the magnification, as well as the surface brightness profile, measuring a S\u00e9rsic index of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn195.gif\" alt=\"${3.50}_{-0.60}^{+0.68}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{3.50}_{-0.60}^{+0.68}</script></span></span> and an <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn196.gif\" alt=\"${r}_{{\\rm{e}}}={0.86}_{-0.14}^{+0.19}\\;\\mathrm{kpc}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{r}_{{\\rm{e}}}={0.86}_{-0.14}^{+0.19}\\;\\mathrm{kpc}</script></span></span>. The right-hand panel of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f8\">8</a> shows the precise <em>r</em><sub>e</sub> measurement of Muzzin et al. (2016, in preparation) as a function of the stellar mass. Over-plotted for comparison are a local, and high-redshift sample. Like the high-redshift sample, our object falls below the local size-mass relation (Shen et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib48\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib48\">2003</a>). We confirm, with a high degree of precision, that this galaxy is compact, which is consistent with what is seen for quiescent galaxies at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn197.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 2</script></span></span> (e.g., Daddi et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib20\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib20\">2005</a>; Trujillo et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib56\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib56\">2006</a>; Zirm et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib77\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib77\">2007</a>; van Dokkum et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib66\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib66\">2008</a>; Szomoru et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib52\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib52\">2012</a>).</p><p>Spectroscopy also allows for a kinematic determination of the mass. The measurement of a dynamical mass is important, as it provides a direct, kinematic method of probing the total matter content of a galaxy, without the uncertainties and prior assumptions associated with parameters such as distance measurement, IMF, and dust content (i.e Conroy et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib19\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib19\">2009</a> places the uncertainty associated with stellar mass estimates to be <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn198.gif\" alt=\"$0.6\\;\\mathrm{dex}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">0.6\\;\\mathrm{dex}</script></span></span> at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn199.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 2</script></span></span>). With the dynamical mass we are able to place a strict upper limit on the baryonic contribution to the total mass of the galaxy. In Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f9\">9</a> we compare the two measurements, and find the stellar and dynamical masses to be consistent with each other, although our results suggest either a low dark matter fraction in the inner kpc of the galaxy, where the bulk of the light is found, or perhaps that the stellar mass content is overestimated within the parameters discussed by Conroy et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib19\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib19\">2009</a>; such as assumptions about the IMF, dust content). However, Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f6\">6</a> shows, via the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn200.gif\" alt=\"$H{\\delta }_{A}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">H{\\delta }_{A}</script></span></span> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn201.gif\" alt=\"${D}_{n}4000$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{D}_{n}4000</script></span></span> indices, a model independent estimation of the age of this object. This result implies consistency in the model choice.</p><p>With a kinematic determination of the mass, and accurately measured structural parameters (<em>r</em><sub>e</sub>, and the S\u00e9rsic index <em>n</em>), we are able to place COSMOS\u00a00050+4901 on the MFP (Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f11\">11</a>). It is well established that local, quiescent galaxies fall on a FP described by surface brightness, size and stellar velocity dispersion (Djorgovski &amp; Davis <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib22\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib22\">1987</a>; Dressler et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib24\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib24\">1987</a>), which is tilted with respect to the prediction from virial equilibrium. This tilt does not evolve significantly, but there is an offset in the plane which becomes larger toward higher redshifts (e.g., van Dokkum &amp; Franx <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib64\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib64\">1996</a>; van Dokkum et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib65\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib65\">1998</a>; Treu et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib55\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib55\">1999</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib54\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib54\">2001</a>) as a result of the luminosity evolution of these galaxies with cosmic time. When replacing the surface brightness with stellar mass density (i.e., the MFP), Bezanson et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib6\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib6\">2013</a>) found that this offset does not evolve significantly and these galaxies fall on the same MFP out to <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn202.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 2</script></span></span>. In Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f11\">11</a> we compare the object in this study to the highest redshift galaxies available with a velocity dispersion measurement. We show that out to <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn203.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 3$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 3</script></span></span> quiescent galaxies fall on the same MFP, and that little evolution takes place between <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn204.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 3$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 3</script></span></span> and the present day.</p><p>A dynamical mass additionally enables the investigation of dark-matter content in the central regions of this galaxy. In Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f10\">10</a>, we have plotted the total-to-stellar mass ratio as a function of redshift, which shows evidence of a trend to decreasing values. However this trend is not statistically significant, as the uncertainties on the dynamical mass at high-<em>z</em> are large. More spectra of these types of objects are required to make a statistically significant claim. If this ratio is low, it is what is expected in the case of a gas-rich, major merger (Robertson et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib45\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib45\">2006</a>; Hopkins et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib28\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib28\">2009</a>), which implies that this galaxy could represent the first generation of quiescent galaxies in the hierarchical merging scenario (White &amp; Rees <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib73\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib73\">1978</a>), making this redshift epoch an exciting prospect for study.</p><p>This case study stands as a proof of concept of the utility of lensed, red galaxies in studying the population of passive galaxies down to lower masses as well as to higher redshifts. This paper also illustrates that few rest-frame optical spectra of quiescent galaxies exist beyond <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn205.gif\" alt=\"$z\\gt 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\gt 2</script></span></span>, and even fewer of galaxies at intermediate mass. We stress the need for further spectra of passive galaxies at higher-redshift, as well as to lower masses, as this parameter space is still under-explored.</p></div> <div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>This research has made use of NASA's Astrophysics Data System. The authors also wish to thank the anonymous referee who's suggestions improved the presentation, and overall clarity of this paper.</p></div></div><!-- End article full text -->\n<!-- Start Footnotes itemtype=\"http://schema.org/Periodical\">\n        <a name=\"\" id=\"skip-to-content-link-target\" tabindex=\"-1\"></a>\n        <div class=\"wrapper grid-3-col da-showgrid ta-showgrid cf\">\n    <main role=\"main\">\n        <!-- Secondary header starts -->\n<div class=\"secondary-header cf\" id=\"wd-secondary-header\">\n    <!-- Branded journal header starts -->\n<div class=\"big-branded\">\n\n    <div class=\"publication-name\" id=\"wd-pub-name\">\n\t<div class=\"publication-title\" itemprop=\"name\" itemid=\"periodical\">\n\t\t\t\t<!-- Journal image link tile starts -->\n<!-- Logo tile starts -->\n<a href=\"/journal/0004-637X\" itemprop=\"url\">\n    <img src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/8febf88b-d09c-11e5-b0b6-759f86a2008e/apj-2016.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The Astrophysical Journal\">\n</a>\n<!-- Logo tile ends -->\n<!-- Journal image link tile ends -->\n</div>\n\t\t</div>\n    <div class=\"partner-logos m-hide\" id=\"wd-partner-logos\">\n            <div class=\"partner-logo-alignment\">\n                <!-- Partner logo tile starts -->\n<a href=\"\" class=\"overlay-launch\">\n    <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/8a2230b8-d09c-11e5-b0b6-759f86a2008e/aas-2018.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The American Astronomical Society, find out more\">\n</a>\n<span class=\"overlay-set\">\n    <div class=\"tint-screen\"></div>\n    <div class=\"overlay-panel\">\n        <a title=\"Close\"  class=\"close-icon close-overlay\" tabindex=\"0\" role=\"button\" aria-describedby=\"close-icon-description\"><span class=\"icon-close\"></span></a>\n        <p id=\"close-icon-description\" class=\"offscreen-hidden\">Click here to close this overlay, or press the \"Escape\" key on your keyboard.</p>\n        <div class=\"overlay-img\">\n            <a href=\"\">\n                <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/8a2230b8-d09c-11e5-b0b6-759f86a2008e/aas-2018.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The American Astronomical Society, find out more\">\n            </a>\n        </div>\n        <div class=\"overlay-text\">\n            <p>The American Astronomical Society (AAS), established in 1899 and based in Washington, DC, is the major organization of professional astronomers in North America. Its membership of about 7,000 individuals also includes physicists, mathematicians, geologists, engineers, and others whose research and educational interests lie within the broad spectrum of subjects comprising contemporary astronomy. The mission of the AAS is to enhance and share humanity's scientific understanding of the universe.</p> <p><a href=\"https://aas.org/\">https://aas.org/</a></div>\n        <p class=\"ta-c mt-1 mb-2\"><a href=\"\"></a></p>\n    </div>\n</span>\n<!-- Partner logo tile ends -->\n\n<!-- Partner logo tile starts -->\n<a href=\"\" class=\"overlay-launch\">\n    <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/7ebd1b32-0439-11e9-b401-cfe9679c40e3/iop-2016.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The Institute of Physics, find out more\">\n</a>\n<span class=\"overlay-set\">\n    <div class=\"tint-screen\"></div>\n    <div class=\"overlay-panel\">\n        <a title=\"Close\"  class=\"close-icon close-overlay\" tabindex=\"0\" role=\"button\" aria-describedby=\"close-icon-description\"><span class=\"icon-close\"></span></a>\n        <p id=\"close-icon-description\" class=\"offscreen-hidden\">Click here to close this overlay, or press the \"Escape\" key on your keyboard.</p>\n        <div class=\"overlay-img\">\n            <a href=\"\">\n                <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/7ebd1b32-0439-11e9-b401-cfe9679c40e3/iop-2016.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The Institute of Physics, find out more\">\n            </a>\n        </div>\n        <div class=\"overlay-text\">\n            <p>The Institute of Physics (IOP) is a leading scientific society promoting physics and bringing physicists together for the benefit of all. It has a worldwide membership of around 50 000 comprising physicists from all sectors, as well as those with an interest in physics. It works to advance physics research, application and education; and engages with policy makers and the public to develop awareness and understanding of physics. Its publishing company, IOP Publishing, is a world leader in professional scientific communications.</p> <p><a href=\"https://www.iop.org\">https://www.iop.org</a></p></div>\n        <p class=\"ta-c mt-1 mb-2\"><a href=\"\"></a></p>\n    </div>\n</span>\n<!-- Partner logo tile ends -->\n\n<p></p>\n                </div>\n        </div>\n    </div>\n<!-- Branded journal header ends -->\n</div> <!-- end secondary-header -->\n<!-- Secondary header ends --><div class=\"da1-da2\" itemscope=\"\" itemtype=\"http://schema.org/ScholarlyArticle\" id=\"page-content\">\n            <div class=\"da1 ta1 article-head\">\n                <!-- Start Eyebrow block, containing Surtitle and Labels -->\n<div class=\"eyebrow\">\n\t<!-- Start Collection Labels -->\n    <!-- End Collection Labels --> </div>\n<!-- End Eyebrow block -->\n\n<h1 itemprop=\"headline\" class=\"wd-jnl-art-title\">A STELLAR VELOCITY DISPERSION FOR A STRONGLY LENSED, INTERMEDIATE-MASS QUIESCENT GALAXY AT <I>z</I> = 2.8</h1>\n\n<p class=\"mb-0\">\n\t<span data-authors=\"\">\n\t\t<span itemtype=\"http://schema.org/Person\" itemprop=\"author\" class=\"nowrap\"><span itemprop=\"name\">Allison. R. href=\"/searchaaskeyword?source=aas&amp;type=kwd_group&amp;code=11%2F43&amp;code_desc=galaxies%3A+structure\">galaxies: structure</a>; <a href=\"/searchaaskeyword?source=aas&amp;type=kwd_group&amp;code=2%2F46&amp;code_desc=gravitational+lensing%3A+strong\">gravitational lensing: strong</a></p>\n\t</div>\n<!-- Start Reprint Link -->\n\t<!-- End Reprint Link --><!-- Start Journal RSS feed -->\n                    <div class=\"jnl-notifications-wrapper jnl-notifications-wrapper--rss\">\n                        <a class=\"wd-jnl-rss\" href=\"/journal/rss/0004-637X\"><span\n                                class=\"icon-feed icon-feed--jhp\"></span>Journal RSS</a>\n                    </div>\n\t\t\t\t\t<!-- End Journal RSS feed -->\n\t\t\t\t\t<!-- Start Email Alert -->\n    <!-- Start Email Alert -->\n        <div class=\"jnl-notifications-wrapper\">\n            <a class=\"wd-jnl-email-alert loginRequired\"\n               href=\"https://myiopscience.iop.org/signin?origin=a0&return=https%3A%2F%2Fiopscience.iop.org%2Farticle%2F10.3847%2F0004-637X%2F819%2F1%2F74\"\n               id=\"corridors-create-manage\" title=\"Create or edit your corridor alerts\">\n                <span class=\"icon-alarm icon-alarm--jhp\"></span>Create or edit your corridor alerts\n            </a>\n\n<!-- Start TOC Subjects Popup -->\n<span class=\"overlay-set\" id=\"corridor-alerts-overlay\">\n    <div class=\"tint-screen\"></div>\n    <div class=\"overlay-panel two-columns\">\n        <div id=\"innerContainer\">\n            <a class=\"close-icon close-overlay\" title=\"Close\" tabindex=\"0\" role=\"button\" aria-describedby=\"close-icon-description\">\n                <span class=\"icon-close\"></span>\n            </a>\n            <p id=\"close-icon-description\" class=\"offscreen-hidden\">\n                Click here to close this overlay, or press the \"Escape\" key on your keyboard.\n            </p>\n            <form id=\"alertsForm\" class=\"overlay-panel__form\" method=\"post\" action=\"\" role=\"form\" aria-labelledby=\"alerts-box-title\">\n                <div class=\"overlay-panel__header\">\n                    <div class=\"overlay-panel__logo\"></div>\n                    <span id=\"alerts-box-title\" class=\"replica-h2\">Corridor alerts</span>\n                    <p id=\"alerts-box-desc\">\n                        Receive alerts on all new research papers in American Astronomical Society\n                        (<span class=\"abbr__aas\">A&nbsp;A&nbsp;S&nbsp;</span>) journals as soon as they are published.\n                        Select your desired journals and corridors below. You will need to select a minimum of one corridor.\n                    </p>\n                </div>\n                <div class=\"overlay-panel__container\">\n                    <div class=\"overlay-panel__col\">\n                        <fieldset id=\"alerts-corridors-list\">\n                            <legend id=\"corridors-title\" class=\"overlay-panel__heading replica-h3 mb-05\">Corridors</legend>\n                        </fieldset>\n                    </div>\n                    <div class=\"overlay-panel__col\">\n                        <fieldset id=\"alerts-journals-list\">\n                            <legend id=\"journals-title\" class=\"overlay-panel__heading replica-h3 mb-05\">Journals</legend>\n                        </fieldset>\n                    </div>\n                    <div class=\"boxout-bg-blue-light overlay-panel__extra-info\">\n                        <p>\n                            Please note, The Astrophysical Journal Letters (ApJL) and Research Notes of the AAS (RNAAS)\n                            do not currently use the corridors.\n                        </p>\n                    </div>\n                </div>\n                <div class=\"overlay-panel__footer\">\n                    <div class=\"overlay-panel__inner-footer\">\n                        <input id=\"update-alerts\" type=\"submit\" value=\"Create alert\" class=\"btn btn-default overlay-panel__btn\" role=\"button\">\n                        <div class=\"icon-spinner spinner overlay-panel__loading\"></div>\n                    </div>\n                </div>\n            </form>\n        </div>\n    </div>\n</span>\n<!-- End TOC Subjects Popup -->\n            <p class=\"mb-0\"><a class=\"wd-jnl-email-alert jnl-email-alert--corridors-info\" href=\"https://journals.aas.org/corridors.html\"\n               target=\"_blank\" title=\"Find out more about AAS corridors.\">\n                What are corridors? <span class=\"icon-newtab\">\n            </a></p>\n        </div>\n\n    <!-- End Email Alert -->\n<!-- End Email Alert --><!-- Start Citation Alert Link -->\n                        <p>\n<div class=\"jnl-notifications-wrapper\">\n    <a class=\"wd-jnl-email-alert\" href=\"https://myiopscience.iop.org/signin?origin=a0&return=https%3A%2F%2Fiopscience.iop.org%2Fmyiopscience%2Falerts%2Fsubscribe%3FarticleID%3D0004-637X%2F819%2F1%2F74\"><span\n            class=\"icon-alarm icon-alarm--jhp\"></span>Create citation alert</a>\n</div><!-- End Citation Alert Link -->\n                    </div>\n\t\t</div>\n    </div>\n    <!-- Article information ends -->\n<!-- Start Info top-->\n    <!-- end Info top --><div class=\"article-content\">\n\t<span id=\"articleId\" class=\"hide\">0004-637X/819/1/74</span>\n<!-- Start Abstract -->\n    <h2 id=\"artAbst\" class=\"collapse-blocked\">Abstract</h2>\n        <!-- Start article video abstract -->\n\t<!-- End article video abstract -->\n\t<div class=\"article-text wd-jnl-art-abstract cf\" itemprop=\"description\">\n            <P>Measuring stellar velocity dispersions of quiescent galaxies beyond <IMG ALIGN=\"MIDDLE\" alt=\"$z\\sim 2$\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/apj522770ieqn1.gif\"></IMG> is observationally challenging. Such measurements require near-infrared spectra with a continuum detection of at least moderate signal to noise, often necessitating long integrations. In this paper, we present deep X-Shooter spectroscopy of one of only two known gravitationally lensed massive quiescent galaxies at <IMG ALIGN=\"MIDDLE\" alt=\"$z\\gt 2$\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/apj522770ieqn2.gif\"></IMG>. This galaxy is quadruply imaged, with the brightest images magnified by a factor of ~5. The total exposure time of our data is 9.8 hr on-source; however, the magnification, and the slit placement encompassing two images, provides a total equivalent exposure time of 215 hr. From this deep spectrum we measure a redshift of (<IMG ALIGN=\"MIDDLE\" alt=\"${z}_{\\mathrm{spec}}=2.756\\pm 0.001$\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/apj522770ieqn3.gif\"></IMG>), making this one of the highest redshift quiescent galaxies that is spectroscopically confirmed. We simultaneously fit both the spectroscopic and photometric data to determine stellar population parameters and conclude that this galaxy is relatively young (<IMG ALIGN=\"MIDDLE\" alt=\"${560}_{-80}^{+100}\\;\\mathrm{Myr}$\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/apj522770ieqn4.gif\"></IMG>), of intermediate mass (<IMG ALIGN=\"MIDDLE\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\;{M}_{*}/{M}_{\\odot }={10.59}_{-0.05}^{+0.04}$\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/apj522770ieqn5.gif\"></IMG>), consistent with low dust content (<IMG ALIGN=\"MIDDLE\" alt=\"${A}_{V}={0.20}_{-0.20}^{+0.26}$\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/apj522770ieqn6.gif\"></IMG>), and has quenched only relatively recently. This recent quenching is confirmed by strong Balmer absorption, particularly <IMG ALIGN=\"MIDDLE\" alt=\"$H\\delta $\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/apj522770ieqn7.gif\"></IMG> (<IMG ALIGN=\"MIDDLE\" alt=\"$H{\\delta }_{A}={6.66}_{-0.92}^{+0.96}$\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/apj522770ieqn8.gif\"></IMG>). Remarkably, this proves that at least some intermediate-mass galaxies have already quenched as early as <IMG ALIGN=\"MIDDLE\" alt=\"$z\\sim 2.8$\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/apj522770ieqn9.gif\"></IMG>. Additionally, we have measured a velocity dispersion of (<IMG ALIGN=\"MIDDLE\" alt=\"$\\sigma =187\\pm 43\\;\\mathrm{km}\\;{{\\rm{s}}}^{-1}$\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/apj522770ieqn10.gif\"></IMG>), making this the highest-redshift quiescent galaxy with a dispersion measurement. We confirm that this galaxy falls on the same mass fundamental plane (MFP) as galaxies at <I>z</I>\u00a0=\u00a02.2, consistent with little to no evolution in the MFP up to <I>z</I>\u00a0=\u00a02.8. Overall this galaxy is proof of the existence of intermediate-mass quenched galaxies in the distant universe, and that lensing is a powerful tool for determining their properties with improved accuracy.</P></div>\n    <!-- End abstract -->\n<!-- Start Export citation and abstract tools -->\n\t<p>\n\t\t<small>Export citation and abstract</small>\n\t\t<span class=\"btn-multi-block\">\n\t\t\t<a href=\"/export?articleId=0004-637X/819/1/74&doi=10.3847/0004-637X/819/1/74&exportFormat=iopexport_bib&exportType=abs&navsubmit=Export+abstract\" class=\"btn btn-primary wd-btn-cit-abs-bib\" title=\"Export BibTex\">BibTeX</a>\n\t\t\t<a href=\"/export?articleId=0004-637X/819/1/74&doi=10.3847/0004-637X/819/1/74&exportFormat=iopexport_ris&exportType=abs&navsubmit=Export+abstract\" class=\"btn btn-primary wd-btn-cit-abs-ris\" title=\"Export RIS\">RIS</a>\n\t\t</span>\n\t</p>\n<!-- End Export citation and abstract tools -->\n<!-- Start AAS Related Links -->\n<div class=\"reveal-container reveal-closed reveal-plus-icon bdt-1 mt-2 mb-2 wd-jnl-art-article-aas-related-links\">\n  <div class=\"replica-h3 mt-0\">\n    <a href=\"#\" class=\"reveal-trigger\" data-reveal-label-alt=\"Hide related links\">Related links</a>\n  </div>\n  <div class=\"reveal-content\">\n    <div class=\"article-meta\"> \n      <ul>\n      \t<li><a href=\"http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2016ApJ...819...74H\" target=\"_blank\">NASA ADS Record <span class=\"icon-newtab\"></span></a></li>\n      \t<li><a href=\"http://nedwww.ipac.caltech.edu/cgi-bin/nph-objsearch?refcode=2016ApJ...819...74H&search_type=Search \" target=\"_blank\">NED Objects <span class=\"icon-newtab\"></span></a></li>\n      \t<li><a href=\"http://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-ref?querymethod=bib&simbo=on&bibcode=2016ApJ...819...74H\" target=\"_blank\">Simbad Objects <span class=\"icon-newtab\"></span></a></li>\n      \t<li><a href=\"/journal/0004-637X/page/About%20Related%20Links\" target=\"_blank\">About Related Links</a></li>\n      \t</ul>\n    </div>\n  </div>\n</div>\n<!-- Start info bottom -->\n    <!-- End info bottom -->\n<!-- Start article full text -->\n\t<div xmlns:book=\"http://api.iop.org/Book/1.0/\" itemprop=\"articleBody\" class=\"wd-jnl-art-full-text article-text\">\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apj522770s1\" name=\"apj522770s1\">1.\u00a0INTRODUCTION</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>It is well established that galaxies with evolved stellar populations were already in place when the universe was less than half of its current age (see for example McCracken et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib34\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib34\">2012</a>; Ilbert et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib29\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib29\">2013</a>; Muzzin et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib38\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib38\">2013b</a>). These galaxies were first identified from a population which exhibited red <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn11.gif\" alt=\"${J}_{{\\rm{s}}}-{K}_{{\\rm{s}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{J}_{{\\rm{s}}}-{K}_{{\\rm{s}}}</script></span></span> colors (Franx et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib25\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib25\">2003</a>). These colors were consistent with taking the spectral energy distribution (SED) of an elliptical or dusty star-burst galaxy and red-shifting to <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn12.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 2</script></span></span>, with the degeneracy between the two types of galaxies lifted with the inclusion of IRAC data (Labb\u00e9 et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib33\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib33\">2005</a>; Williams et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib74\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib74\">2009</a>). From the Franx et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib25\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib25\">2003</a>) sample, subsequent spectroscopy later confirmed that a subset of these \"red galaxies\" were indeed quiescent (van Dokkum et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib63\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib63\">2003</a>; Kriek et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib31\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib31\">2006</a>), establishing that galaxies with strongly suppressed star formation were present at higher redshifts.</p><p>A comparison of the stellar populations of quiescent galaxies between <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn13.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 2</script></span></span> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn14.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 0$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 0</script></span></span> via their mass-to-light ratios show that the stellar populations in these galaxies are consistent with passive evolution (e.g., van Dokkum et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib65\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib65\">1998</a>; Treu et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib55\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib55\">1999</a>; Bernardi et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib5\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib5\">2003</a>; van Dokkum et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib68\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib68\">2006</a>). Although quiescent, the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn15.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 2</script></span></span> galaxies are strikingly different in their structure compared to present-day ellipticals. At a given mass, their effective radii (<em>r</em><sub>e</sub>) are a factor of ~2\u20134 smaller than at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn16.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 0$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 0</script></span></span> (e.g., Daddi et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib20\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib20\">2005</a>; Trujillo et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib56\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib56\">2006</a>; Zirm et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib77\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib77\">2007</a>; van Dokkum et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib66\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib66\">2008</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib69\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib69\">2010</a>; Szomoru et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib52\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib52\">2012</a>). This difference in <em>r</em><sub>e</sub> between present-day ellipticals and high-redshift galaxies implies a rapid structural evolution between <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn17.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 2</script></span></span> and today. Although these galaxies must grow by a factor of a few in size, their central stellar-velocity dispersions show little evolution (Toft et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib53\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib53\">2012</a>; Bezanson et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib6\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib6\">2013</a>; van de Sande et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib60\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib60\">2013</a>; Belli et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib3\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib3\">2014a</a>) between these redshifts.</p><p>The evolution of stellar populations between redshift <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn18.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 2</script></span></span> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn19.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 0$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 0</script></span></span> is mirrored in the evolution of the zero-point in the fundamental plane (FP). The FP represents a locus of galaxies which occupy a tight plane determined by a galaxy's surface brightness, size and velocity dispersion (Djorgovski &amp; Davis <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib22\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib22\">1987</a>; Dressler et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib24\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib24\">1987</a>). This plane maintains a slight tilt with respect to the expectation from the assumption of virial equilibrium. This tilt is thought to be caused by a deviation from homology (Capelato et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib14\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib14\">1995</a>; Pahre et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib43\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib43\">1995</a>; Busarello et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib12\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib12\">1997</a>), and by variations in the mass-to-light ratio (van Dokkum et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib65\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib65\">1998</a>; Cappellari et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib15\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib15\">2006</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib17\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib17\">2013</a>; Robertson et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib45\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib45\">2006</a>; Bolton et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib7\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib7\">2007</a>).</p><p>When the dependence of the FP on surface brightness is replaced with the average stellar mass density (i.e., the mass fundamental plane; henceforth MFP), the tilt in the FP virtually disappears (Bolton et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib7\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib7\">2007</a>), or is at least shown to be weaker than the tilt in the FP (Bolton et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib8\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib8\">2008</a>; Holden et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib27\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib27\">2010</a>; Bezanson et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib6\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib6\">2013</a>). In contrast to the evolution in the zero-point of the FP (e.g., van de Sande et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib57\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib57\">2014</a>), the MFP zero-point shows very little evolution out to <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn20.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 2</script></span></span> (Bezanson et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib6\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib6\">2013</a>), reminiscent of the lack of evolution in central stellar-velocity dispersion (Toft et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib53\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib53\">2012</a>; Bezanson et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib6\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib6\">2013</a>; Belli et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib3\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib3\">2014a</a>). However the precise evolution depends on assumptions when counting galaxies and how to connect progenitors to their descendants (van de Sande et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib57\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib57\">2014</a>).</p><p>The consistency of the slope of the MFP with that predicted from virial equilibrium points to variations in mass-to-light ratios as the likely cause of the tilt in the FP. The evolution in mass-to-light ratios is driven by either variations in dark matter content, variations in stellar populations, or a combination of both. In the context of MFP evolution at high-<em>z</em>, it is important to note that the sample of Bezanson et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib6\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib6\">2013</a> in the highest redshift bin was restricted to massive galaxies, i.e., <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn21.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\;{M}_{*}/{M}_{\\odot }\\gt 11.0$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\;{M}_{*}/{M}_{\\odot }\\gt 11.0</script></span></span>, leaving the MFP unpopulated below this mass threshold at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn22.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 2</script></span></span>, and due to redshift coverage, at all masses above <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn23.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 2</script></span></span>.</p><p>Although valuable for testing the evolution of the MPF, measuring stellar velocity dispersions of quiescent galaxies beyond <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn24.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 2</script></span></span> has proven technically challenging. At these redshifts their optical absorption lines are redshifted to the near-infrared (NIR) which has a high and variable sky background. In contrast to actively star-forming galaxies, measuring a stellar-velocity dispersion of quiescent galaxies requires a continuum detection, with moderate signal-to-noise ratios (S/N). Because of the long integration times required to achieve the necessary S/N enabling a stellar velocity dispersion measurement, the community has been restricted to observing the brightest galaxies at these redshifts (Onodera et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib41\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib41\">2010</a>; van de Sande et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib59\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib59\">2011</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib60\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib60\">2013</a>; Toft et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib53\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib53\">2012</a>; Bezanson et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib6\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib6\">2013</a>; Belli et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib3\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib3\">2014a</a>), which van de Sande et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib57\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib57\">2014</a>) showed is also biased toward younger post-starburst galaxies.</p><p>In order to probe higher redshifts and/or lower masses, and circumvent the need for long integration times prior to the era of the <em>James Webb Space Telescope</em> (<em>JWST</em>), we aim to take advantage of the brightening and magnifying effects of strong gravitational lensing. This tool has been successfully implemented in studying the properties of distant star-forming galaxies, with higher resolution and better signal-to-noise than normally possible including lyman-break (e.g., Smail et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib49\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib49\">2007</a>), sub-millimetre (e.g., Vieira et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib71\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib71\">2013</a>) and UV-bright galaxies (e.g., Brammer et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib9\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib9\">2012</a>; Sharon et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib47\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib47\">2012</a>; van der Wel et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib62\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib62\">2013</a>). We aim to extend the utility of gravitational lensing to red, quiescent galaxies.</p><p>Lensed, quiescent galaxies at high redshifts (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn25.gif\" alt=\"$z\\gt 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\gt 2</script></span></span>) are comparably more difficult to find than lensed star-forming galaxies for a variety of reasons. First quiescent galaxies show a declining number density with increasing redshift (i.e., Muzzin et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib38\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib38\">2013b</a>). Thus, there are fewer quiescent galaxies to be lensed at high redshift as compared to star-forming galaxies. Second, blue, lensed star-forming galaxies stand out in red, quiescently dominated galaxy clusters, whereas red, lensed galaxies do not. One of the best places to search for lensed galaxies is behind galaxy clusters as they have deep potential wells. As a result of high star formation rates (SFR), SMGs exhaust their gas on relatively short timescales, and are thus extremely rare in local galaxy clusters. Because of SMG rarity in local clusters, the foreground lensing cluster has few sources in the sub-mm images allowing for trivial detection of the lensed SMGs. This is not the case for quiescent galaxies, where the foreground cluster is also NIR bright. Blue, star-forming galaxies are UV-bright, and lensed candidates at redshift ~2 have this emission shifted to the rest-frame optical, making the high-redshift blue galaxies behind clusters optically bright. With the existence of wide and relatively deep optical surveys such as SDSS, there is a wealth of lensed blue galaxies (e.g, Stark et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib50\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib50\">2013</a>), however large area NIR surveys of comparable depth are not available.</p><p>As such, there are only five red, lensed galaxies presented in the literature. Auger et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib1\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib1\">2011</a>) present an intermediate redshift (<em>z</em> = 0.6) lensed candidate which is multiply imaged. Two of the high-redshift (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn26.gif\" alt=\"$z=1.71,2.15$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z=1.71,2.15</script></span></span>) examples in the literature (Geier et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib26\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib26\">2013</a>) are singly imaged, which are more difficult to create lens models for. There are only two examples of multiply imaged red-lenses at high redshift. One, found by Newman et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib39\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib39\">2015</a>), with a spectroscopic redshift of <em>z</em> = 2.636, and the other is the object of this study which was first identified by Muzzin et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib36\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib36\">2012</a>).</p><p>In this paper we present X-Shooter spectroscopy, and a stellar velocity dispersion measurement of COSMOS 0050+4901, a quiescent galaxy found by Muzzin et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib36\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib36\">2012</a>) in the COSMOS/UltraVISTA field (McCracken et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib34\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib34\">2012</a>). With the current data, this is now the highest redshift quiescent galaxy with a stellar velocity dispersion measurement, as well as the least massive quiescent galaxy beyond redshift 2 with a rest-frame optical spectrum.</p><p>We assume a <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn27.gif\" alt=\"${\\rm{\\Lambda }}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\rm{\\Lambda }}</script></span></span>-CDM cosmology (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn28.gif\" alt=\"${H}_{0}=70\\;\\mathrm{km}\\;{{\\rm{s}}}^{-1}\\;{\\mathrm{Mpc}}^{-1}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{H}_{0}=70\\;\\mathrm{km}\\;{{\\rm{s}}}^{-1}\\;{\\mathrm{Mpc}}^{-1}</script></span></span>, <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn29.gif\" alt=\"${{\\rm{\\Omega }}}_{M}=0.3$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{{\\rm{\\Omega }}}_{M}=0.3</script></span></span>, and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn30.gif\" alt=\"${{\\rm{\\Omega }}}_{{\\rm{\\Lambda }}}=0.7$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{{\\rm{\\Omega }}}_{{\\rm{\\Lambda }}}=0.7</script></span></span>), and AB magnitudes.</p></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apj522770s2\" name=\"apj522770s2\">2.\u00a0DATA</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><h3 id=\"apj522770s2-1\" name=\"apj522770s2-1\">2.1.\u00a0COSMOS 0050+4901</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>COSMOS 0050+4901 is a strongly lensed system where the lens is a single galaxy at <em>z</em> = 0.960 found serendipitously in the COSMOS/UltraVISTA field (McCracken et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib34\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib34\">2012</a>) as a group of exceptionally bright, red galaxies. The source is quadruply imaged, with photometric redshifts of <em>z</em> ~ 2.3\u20132.4 (depending on which of the multiple images is analyzed; Muzzin et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib36\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib36\">2012</a>, hereafter <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib36\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib36\">M12</a>). The brightest three images are magnified by a factor of ~5 (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib36\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib36\">M12</a>, Muzzin et al. 2016, in preparation). In Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f1\">1</a> we show a 3-color UltraVISTA J-, H-, and Ks-band image of the lens-source system. Included in this figure is the placement of the slit used for the spectroscopic data (see Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj522770s2-3\">2.3</a>). As illustrated by the slit position shown in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f1\">1</a>, we have obtained spectroscopy of two images, effectively doubling our exposure time. Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f1\">1</a> also qualitatively illustrates the difference in color between the foreground lens and the source images as a result of their differing redshifts.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj522770f1\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj522770f1\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770f1_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 1.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 1.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770f1_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 1.</strong>\u00a0RGB-image using UltraVISTA Ks-, H-, and J-band DR2 images. The source images are labeled A, B, C, and D, and the foreground lens is indicated. The source images are noticeably redder than the lens because of the discordant redshifts (<span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn31.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{\\mathrm{lens}}=0.960$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{\\mathrm{lens}}=0.960</script></span></span> and <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn32.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{\\mathrm{source}}=2.76$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{\\mathrm{source}}=2.76</script></span></span>) which result in the continuum emission from the lens and source galaxies peaking in different bands. The position of the X-Shooter slit on the sky is indicated. Note that the slit was placed such that it falls on galaxies A and B.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj522770f1\" href=\"/0004-637X/819/1/74/downloadFigure/figure/apj522770f1\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj522770f1\" href=\"/0004-637X/819/1/74/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj522770f1\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p>\n<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib36\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib36\">M12</a> performed an initial estimate of the structural properties of the galaxy using the ground-based <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn33.gif\" alt=\"${K}_{s}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{K}_{s}</script></span></span>-band data. Assuming the best photometric redshift at that time, they estimated <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn34.gif\" alt=\"${r}_{{\\rm{e}}}={0.64}_{-0.18}^{+0.08}\\;\\mathrm{kpc}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{r}_{{\\rm{e}}}={0.64}_{-0.18}^{+0.08}\\;\\mathrm{kpc}</script></span></span> and a S\u00e9rsic index of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn35.gif\" alt=\"$n={2.2}_{-0.9}^{+2.3}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">n={2.2}_{-0.9}^{+2.3}</script></span></span>. Recently, we obtained high-resolution HST\u00a0F160W imaging of COSMOS\u00a00050+4901. With the deep HST image and spectroscopic redshift determined in this analysis, A. Muzzin et al. (2016, in preparation) determined a well-constrained lens model, which allowed them to accurately determine the circularized <em>r</em><sub>e</sub> (corrected for magnification) and <em>n</em> to be <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn36.gif\" alt=\"${0.86}_{-0.14}^{+0.19}\\;\\mathrm{kpc}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{0.86}_{-0.14}^{+0.19}\\;\\mathrm{kpc}</script></span></span> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn37.gif\" alt=\"${3.50}_{-0.60}^{+0.68}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{3.50}_{-0.60}^{+0.68}</script></span></span>.</p></div><h3 id=\"apj522770s2-2\" name=\"apj522770s2-2\">2.2.\u00a0Rest-frame UVJ Colors</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>Williams et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib74\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib74\">2009</a>) demonstrate that galaxies display a clear bi-modality in <em>U</em>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>V</em> and <em>V</em>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>J</em> color-space out to <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a02. Galaxies tend to separate into two sequences in color\u2013color space, one consisting primarily of star-forming galaxies, and one primarily consisting of quiescent galaxies. This bi-modality is driven by a galaxy's UV+IR determined SFR. Beyond <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a02, measurement errors, and completeness limits reduces this bi-modailty (Williams et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib74\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib74\">2009</a>; Muzzin et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib38\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib38\">2013b</a>).</p><p>We calculate the rest-frame <em>U</em>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>V</em> and <em>V</em>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>J</em> colors for <em>COSMOS</em>\u00a0 0050+4901 using the photometric data presented in <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib36\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib36\">M12</a> (via <em>EAZY</em>; Brammer et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib10\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib10\">2008</a>). We de-blending the lens from the images, which showed non-negligible contamination in the PSF-matched ground based imaging, by simultaneously fitting both the images and the lens using <em>GALFIT</em> (Peng et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib44\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib44\">2010</a>; further details may be found in <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib36\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib36\">M12</a>).</p><p>In Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f2\">2</a> we show that our object falls on the quiescent region in the <em>UVJ</em> diagram (using <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn38.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{\\mathrm{spec}}=2.756;$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{\\mathrm{spec}}=2.756;</script></span></span> the determination of which is described in Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj522770s3-1\">3.1</a>). We compare and contrast it to a quiescent, spectroscopic sample compilation (from van de Sande et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib58\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib58\">2015</a>), with a redshift distribution of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn39.gif\" alt=\"$0.6\\lt z\\lt 2.2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">0.6\\lt z\\lt 2.2</script></span></span>). This sample contains 63 galaxies at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn40.gif\" alt=\"$0.4\\lt z\\lt 1.6$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">0.4\\lt z\\lt 1.6</script></span></span> from Bezanson et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib6\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib6\">2013</a>), 38 galaxies at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn41.gif\" alt=\"$1\\lt z\\lt 1.4$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">1\\lt z\\lt 1.4</script></span></span> from Belli et al.
