(<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib3\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib3\">2014a</a>), 18 galaxies at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn42.gif\" alt=\"$0.6\\lt z\\lt 1.1$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">0.6\\lt z\\lt 1.1</script></span></span> from van der Wel et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib61\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib61\">2005</a>), 16 galaxies at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn43.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 0.8$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 0.8</script></span></span> from Wuyts et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib76\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib76\">2004</a>), 5 galaxies at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn44.gif\" alt=\"$1.2\\lt z\\lt 1.6$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">1.2\\lt z\\lt 1.6</script></span></span> from Newman et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib40\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib40\">2010</a>), 4 galaxies at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn45.gif\" alt=\"$1.4\\lt z\\lt 2.1$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">1.4\\lt z\\lt 2.1</script></span></span> from van de Sande et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib60\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib60\">2013</a>), 3 galaxies at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn46.gif\" alt=\"$2.1\\lt z\\lt 2.4$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">2.1\\lt z\\lt 2.4</script></span></span> from Belli et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib4\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib4\">2014b</a>), 1 galaxy at <em>z</em> = 2.2 from van Dokkum et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib67\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib67\">2009</a>), 1 galaxy at <em>z</em> = 1.8 from Onodera et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib42\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib42\">2012</a>), and 1 galaxy at <em>z</em> = 2.6 from Newman et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib39\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib39\">2015</a>; see Table in van de Sande et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib58\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib58\">2015</a> for further details). As stated in van de Sande et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib58\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib58\">2015</a>), the sample is selected based on the availability of kinematic measurements in the literature. Thus, this sample is biased toward brighter objects. In Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f2\">2</a> we also indicate the <em>UVJ</em> color selection from van de Sande et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib58\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib58\">2015</a>) as the dashed black line.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj522770f2\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj522770f2\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770f2_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 2.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 2.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770f2_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 2.</strong>\u00a0Rest-frame <em>U</em>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>V</em> color vs. <em>V</em>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>J</em> color. Gray points are a redshift selected (<span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn47.gif\" alt=\"$1.5\\lt z\\lt 2.5$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">1.5\\lt z\\lt 2.5</script></span></span>) comparison sample from the K<sub>s</sub>-band selected UVISTA catalog (McCracken et al. <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib34\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib34\">2012</a>). The black dashed line is the color selection implemented by van de Sande et al. (<a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib58\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib58\">2015</a>) to separate quiescent and star-forming galaxies. Colored points are a high-redshift (<span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn48.gif\" alt=\"$0.6\\lt z\\lt 2.3$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">0.6\\lt z\\lt 2.3</script></span></span>) sample compiled by van de Sande et al. (<a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib58\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib58\">2015</a>), with the literature sources indicated in the plot legend. Our object (orange star) sits on the UVISTA <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn49.gif\" alt=\"$1.5\\lt z\\lt 2.5$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">1.5\\lt z\\lt 2.5</script></span></span> red sequence, and within the locus of other high-redshift, quiescent galaxies with measured stellar velocity dispersions.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj522770f2\" href=\"/0004-637X/819/1/74/downloadFigure/figure/apj522770f2\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj522770f2\" href=\"/0004-637X/819/1/74/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj522770f2\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p>Also plotted in grayscale in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f2\">2</a> is a redshift-selected (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn50.gif\" alt=\"$1.5\\lt z\\lt 2.5$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">1.5\\lt z\\lt 2.5</script></span></span>), photometric sub-sample from the K-band selected catalog of UltraVISTA from Muzzin et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib37\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib37\">2013a</a>; with the limiting magnitude <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn51.gif\" alt=\"$K\\lt 24.4$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">K\\lt 24.4</script></span></span> in a <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn52.gif\" alt=\"$2\\buildrel{\\prime\\prime}\\over{.} 1$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">2\\buildrel{\\prime\\prime}\\over{.} 1</script></span></span> aperture). This sub-sample contains both star-forming, and quiescent galaxies. The redshift range was chosen in order to highlight the color bi-modality, which as previously mentioned, is erased at higher redshifts due to incompleteness and measurement errors. In comparison to both the spectroscopic and photometric samples, our object has colors similar to galaxies with quiescent populations.</p></div><h3 id=\"apj522770s2-3\" name=\"apj522770s2-3\">2.3.\u00a0Spectroscopic Data</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>Data were obtained using the X-Shooter instrument on VLT UT2 (D'Odorico et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib23\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib23\">2006</a>; Vernet et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib70\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib70\">2011</a>) with the K-band blocking filter in place. The target was observed in service mode; the observations were carried out between 2012 December and 2014 February (program Muzzin 090.B-0452(A), and DDT program Muzzin 288.B-5043(A)). All observations had clear sky conditions and an average seeing of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn53.gif\" alt=\"$0\\buildrel{\\prime\\prime}\\over{.} 8$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">0\\buildrel{\\prime\\prime}\\over{.} 8</script></span></span>. A <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn54.gif\" alt=\"$0\\buildrel{\\prime\\prime}\\over{.} 9$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">0\\buildrel{\\prime\\prime}\\over{.} 9</script></span></span> slit was used in the NIR, aligned in the north\u2013south direction with two of the images on the slit, as shown in the UltraVISTA color image in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f1\">1</a>. X-Shooter simultaneously takes spectra in the observed UVB and VIS. The UVB and VIS arm data had no signal, as expected from the very red SED.</p><p>The NIR sky changes on short timescales (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn55.gif\" alt=\"$\\sim \\mathrm{minutes}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\sim \\mathrm{minutes}</script></span></span>) and to compensate for changing sky levels, it is customary to perform a nodding pattern, with two frames adjacent in time subtracted from each other with the object offset in adjacent frames, often referred to as an ABBA observing pattern. Given the size of the X-Shooter slit (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn56.gif\" alt=\"$0\\buildrel{\\prime\\prime}\\over{.} 9\\;$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">0\\buildrel{\\prime\\prime}\\over{.} 9\\;</script></span></span> <b>&#x00d7;</b> 11''), the spatial extent of our object was such that there was insufficient space to perform this nodding pattern with enough empty sky for a successful sky subtraction. As such, observing blocks were 10 minutes, with a nodding pattern offset in declination in <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn57.gif\" alt=\"$0\\buildrel{\\prime\\prime}\\over{.} 4$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">0\\buildrel{\\prime\\prime}\\over{.} 4</script></span></span> increments to a maximum offset of 2'' which corresponds to a shift on the slit of between 2 and 10 pixels. These offsets were made for the identification and removal of bad pixels.</p><p>The images were reduced using the method most commonly used in optical spectroscopy (see Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj522770s2-4\">2.4</a>). Of 64 science frames with 600 s exposure of exposure time on each frame, 5 frames did not contain the target and were thus not used in the final combination (but utilized in sky subtraction\u2014see Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj522770s2-4\">2.4</a>). This results in a science image with a total exposure time of 9.8 hr. However, obtaining a similar S/N spectrum on a single galaxy with comparable un-lensed magnitude (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn58.gif\" alt=\"$K\\sim 22.7$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">K\\sim 22.7</script></span></span>) would require 215 hr when accounting for the fact that our observations are sky-limited, 2 objects fall on the slit and that we are only semi-resolved. This gain in S/N demonstrates the substantial observing advantage provided by strong gravitational lensing. Additionally, a B9V telluric standard star (Hipparcos 049704) was also observed before and after the science target for removal of atmospheric absorption lines, as well as relative flux calibration between orders.</p></div><h3 id=\"apj522770s2-4\" name=\"apj522770s2-4\">2.4.\u00a0Spectroscopic Reduction</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>The data were reduced with the ESO pipeline for X-Shooter (ver 3.10; Modigliani et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib35\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib35\">2010</a>), following the \"physical\" mode reduction chain using EsoRex. Individual frames were reduced in stare mode, as the extent of the object on the slit made standard sky subtraction difficult. Bad-pixel masks were generated using IRAF task <em>ccd</em>_<em>mask</em>, and bad-pixels corrected for using the IRAF task <em>fixpix</em>.</p><p>Because of the methodology of our sky subtraction, we found several detector artefacts on the images which complicated this procedure. In order to subtract these artefacts, we generated a sky frame out of 5 blank sky frames from our observations, as well as other 10 minutes exposures which used the K-band blocking filter found in the X-Shooter archive. We used a total of 28 frames. These frames were all median combined to generate a high S/N sky-frame. This sky-frame was then subtracted from the science frames to subtract the detector artefacts.</p><p>The OH-emission lines in the NIR vary in flux, and change on short timescales, so the sky-frame subtraction could not account for sky lines. To account for this, the sky was modeled along each column in the spatial direction, while masking out rows which contained galaxy flux. This modeled sky was then subtracted from each column. The individual exposures were then median combined order by order.</p><p>The telluric standard spectra were reduced in the same way as the science frames. We constructed a response spectrum from the telluric star, and a black body curve with a <em>T</em><sub>eff</sub> matching a B9V star. Residuals from Balmer absorption in the telluric standard were removed by interpolation. The science observations were corrected for instrumental response and atmospheric absorption by division of the response spectrum.</p><p>To extract the spectrum, a one-dimensional (1D) light profile was fit to each wavelength pixel (or column) along the spatial direction. The light profile was modeled from a median combination of all these fitted profiles from an order in the H band (the highest S/N region of our spectrum). Order number 17 is shown in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f3\">3</a> to illustrate. The light profile found in the top panel of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f3\">3</a> was fit, with a background term, to each column of the combined, two-dimensional (2D) spectrum:</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj522770eqn1\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770eqn1.gif\" alt=\"Equation (1)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{c}_{\\lambda }={a}_{\\lambda }{P}_{y}+{b}_{\\lambda }\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t1\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>\n</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj522770f3\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj522770f3\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770f3_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 3.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 3.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770f3_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 3.</strong>\u00a0Above is an example of our prescription for column rejection and spectral extraction. From to to bottom: (1) The median combined 2D spectrum. (2) The model reconstruction from the double gaussian fitting as described in \"Spectroscopic Reduction.\" (3) The residuals of (1) and (2). (4) The coefficient of the relative strength of the double-peak profile (effectively the extracted 1D spectrum with normalized units). (5) The coefficient of the background term. (6) The relative error error from the fit. The columns are rejected above a specified \"Fit Error\" which varied with each spectral order. The blue shaded regions in (1) and (2) are the columns which are rejected.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj522770f3\" href=\"/0004-637X/819/1/74/downloadFigure/figure/apj522770f3\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj522770f3\" href=\"/0004-637X/819/1/74/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj522770f3\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p><em>\u03bb</em> and <em>y</em> refer to the spatial and spectral dimensions. <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn59.gif\" alt=\"${c}_{\\lambda }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{c}_{\\lambda }</script></span></span> refers to the column, <em>P</em><sub><em>y</em></sub> is the double peaked profile fit to each column, <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn60.gif\" alt=\"${a}_{\\lambda }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{a}_{\\lambda }</script></span></span> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn61.gif\" alt=\"${b}_{\\lambda }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{b}_{\\lambda }</script></span></span> are the fitted coefficients. <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn62.gif\" alt=\"${a}_{\\lambda }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{a}_{\\lambda }</script></span></span> is effectively the 1D spectrum, and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn63.gif\" alt=\"${b}_{\\lambda }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{b}_{\\lambda }</script></span></span> is the background term (see the fourth and fifth panels in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f3\">3</a>). The error spectrum (bottom panel of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f3\">3</a>) is the covariance of the fit, using the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn64.gif\" alt=\"$1\\sigma $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">1\\sigma</script></span></span> value of the pixels at each location. Skylines and bad columns were flagged using an error cutoff (above which the columns would be rejected).</p><p>The low-resolution spectrum was constructed by binning the 1D spectrum in the wavelength direction, using a bi-weight mean (as described in van de Sande et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib60\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib60\">2013</a>) with a bin size of 10 good pixels. We show the spectrum, along with photometry and the best-fit BC03 model in Figures <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f4\">4</a> and <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f5\">5</a>.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj522770f4\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj522770f4\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770f4_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 4.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 4.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770f4_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 4.</strong>\u00a0Best-fit FAST BC03 template (red-line) with photometry (blue points) and H-band X-Shooter spectrum (black-line). Gray regions indicate strong atmospheric absorption resulting in low S/N spectra. The J-band spectrum was omitted due to contamination from the lensing galaxy (see text for further discussion). Best-fit stellar population parameters and their 68% confidence intervals can be found in Table <a class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj522770t1\">1</a>.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj522770f4\" href=\"/0004-637X/819/1/74/downloadFigure/figure/apj522770f4\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj522770f4\" href=\"/0004-637X/819/1/74/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj522770f4\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj522770f5\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj522770f5\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770f5_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 5.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 5.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770f5_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 5.</strong>\u00a0Similar to Figure <a href=\"#apj522770f4\">4</a>, but with the wavelength range restricted to the H band, and the location of prominent absorption lines indicated. The fitted spectrum was smoothed using a bi-weight mean with a bin size of 10 good points (i.e., those that were not rejected by our criteria described in Section <a class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj522770s2-3\">2.3</a>). The spectrum shown above has been smoothed to better illustrate the presence of absorption lines.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj522770f5\" href=\"/0004-637X/819/1/74/downloadFigure/figure/apj522770f5\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj522770f5\" href=\"/0004-637X/819/1/74/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj522770f5\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure></div></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apj522770s3\" name=\"apj522770s3\">3.\u00a0STRUCTURAL PROPERTIES AND STELLAR POPULATIONS</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><h3 id=\"apj522770s3-1\" name=\"apj522770s3-1\">3.1.\u00a0Redshift Determination</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>A spectroscopic redshift was measured using FAST (Kriek et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib32\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib32\">2009</a>), an IDL-based fitting routine which fits stellar population synthesis models to photometry/spectra. This fitting is described in more detail in Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj522770s3-2\">3.2</a>.</p><p>Our best-fit redshift is <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn65.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{\\mathrm{spec}}=2.756\\pm 0.001$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{\\mathrm{spec}}=2.756\\pm 0.001</script></span></span>. This is a high-confidence measurement, as numerous absorption lines, such as <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn66.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{Ca}\\;{\\rm{H}}\\quad \\mathrm{and}\\quad {\\rm{K}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{Ca}\\;{\\rm{H}}\\quad \\mathrm{and}\\quad {\\rm{K}}</script></span></span>, <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn67.gif\" alt=\"$H\\delta $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">H\\delta</script></span></span>, and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn68.gif\" alt=\"$H\\gamma $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">H\\gamma</script></span></span> are detected. Notably, the difference between the photometric (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn69.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{\\mathrm{phot}}=2.4\\pm 0.13$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{\\mathrm{phot}}=2.4\\pm 0.13</script></span></span>) and spectroscopic redshift (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn70.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{\\mathrm{spec}}=2.756\\pm 0.001$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{\\mathrm{spec}}=2.756\\pm 0.001</script></span></span>) is more than twice the uncertainty on the photometric redshift. The possible explanations for this discrepancy are discussed below.</p><p>The difference between the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn71.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{\\mathrm{spec}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{\\mathrm{spec}}</script></span></span> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn72.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{\\mathrm{phot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{\\mathrm{phot}}</script></span></span> might originate from mistaking the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn73.gif\" alt=\"$4000\\;\\mathring{\\rm A} $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">4000\\;\\mathring{\\rm A}</script></span></span> break and Balmer-break. The <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn74.gif\" alt=\"$4000\\;\\mathring{\\rm A} $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">4000\\;\\mathring{\\rm A}</script></span></span> break and Balmer-break (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn75.gif\" alt=\"$\\sim 3640\\;\\mathring{\\rm A} $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\sim 3640\\;\\mathring{\\rm A}</script></span></span>) are two continuum features which are difficult to resolve in photometric data sets due to their proximity in wavelength. Both continuum features result in a color differential between each side of the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn76.gif\" alt=\"$4000\\;\\mathring{\\rm A} $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">4000\\;\\mathring{\\rm A}</script></span></span>/<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn77.gif\" alt=\"$3650\\;\\mathring{\\rm A} $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">3650\\;\\mathring{\\rm A}</script></span></span> spectral region, the strength of which correlates with age in both cases. They do, however, originate from different physical processes, and thus <em>how</em> they correlate with age is different. The <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn78.gif\" alt=\"$4000\\;\\mathring{\\rm A} $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">4000\\;\\mathring{\\rm A}</script></span></span> break is a result of absorption by ionized metals which is strongest in older and high-metallicity stellar populations. The Balmer-break marks the limit of the Balmer series and blending of higher order Balmer lines, and is strongest in A-stars. The strength of the Balmer-break monotonically increases before peaking at intermediate ages (~0.5\u20131 Gyr) when the stellar light is dominated by A-stars.</p><p>Both these features can be prominent in the continuum of quiescent galaxies, and fall into the NIR between <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn79.gif\" alt=\"$1.5\\lt z\\lt 3$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">1.5\\lt z\\lt 3</script></span></span>. The discrepancy between the <em>z</em><sub>phot</sub> and <em>z</em><sub>spec</sub> determination is likely caused by a combination of wavelength gaps between the transmission curves in the NIR bands (J, H, and K<sub>s</sub>), as well as wide bandwidth in the same filters. This results in a <em>J</em>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>H</em> color appropriately explained by either the presence of the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn80.gif\" alt=\"$4000\\;\\mathring{\\rm A} $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">4000\\;\\mathring{\\rm A}</script></span></span> break at lower <em>z</em>, or the Balmer-break at higher <em>z</em>.</p><p>This uncertainty associated with the breaks falling between the NIR filters likely caused the fitting confusion between a quiescent galaxy with a prominent <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn81.gif\" alt=\"$4000\\;\\mathring{\\rm A} $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">4000\\;\\mathring{\\rm A}</script></span></span> break at <em>z</em> = 2.4, and a post-SB galaxy with a <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn82.gif\" alt=\"$3650\\;\\mathring{\\rm A} $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">3650\\;\\mathring{\\rm A}</script></span></span> Balmer-break at <em>z</em> = 2.8. This illustrates the challenges of using <em>z</em><sub>phot</sub> only. This issue is well known, and that even with high S/N NIR photometry, photometric redshifts at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn83.gif\" alt=\"$z\\gt 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\gt 2</script></span></span> can be uncertain due to these issues. This has led to the use of NIR \"medium bands\" as in the NEWFIRM Medium Band Survey (Whitaker et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib72\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib72\">2011</a>) and zFOURGE Survey (Straatman et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib51\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib51\">2014</a>) to provide improved photometric redshifts for galaxies where the Balmer and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn84.gif\" alt=\"$4000\\;\\mathring{\\rm A} $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">4000\\;\\mathring{\\rm A}</script></span></span> breaks fall in the observed NIR.</p><p>This redshift difference is large enough that it changes the stellar population parameters by <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib36\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib36\">M12</a> at a level that is larger than the quoted uncertainties in that paper, particularly the stellar mass, age, and dust content. In the next section we present revised values for these parameters using the spectroscopic redshift.</p></div><h3 id=\"apj522770s3-2\" name=\"apj522770s3-2\">3.2.\u00a0Stellar Population Properties</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>Stellar population properties are estimated using FAST (Kriek et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib32\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib32\">2009</a>). We used Bruzual &amp; Charlot (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib11\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib11\">2003</a>) templates, with a delayed, exponentially declining star formation history (with timescale <em>\u03c4</em>), a Chabrier (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib18\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib18\">2003</a>) IMF, and Calzetti et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib13\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib13\">2000</a>) dust law.</p><p>We have simultaneously fit both the photometry and H-band spectrum. We have omitted the J-band spectrum but include the J-band photometry. The spectrum in the J band is very low S/N as the flux from the lens peaks in the J band (see Figure 4 of <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib36\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib36\">M12</a>). The image and lens are spatially close with contamination affecting the continuum strength. The best fit parameters are summarized in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj522770t1\">1</a>. The best-fit stellar population parameters provide a best-fit FAST age <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn85.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\;\\mathrm{Age}\\;{\\mathrm{years}}^{-1}={8.75}_{-0.07}^{+0.07}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\;\\mathrm{Age}\\;{\\mathrm{years}}^{-1}={8.75}_{-0.07}^{+0.07}</script></span></span>, stellar-mass <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn86.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\;{M}_{*}/{M}_{\\odot }={10.59}_{-0.05}^{+0.04}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\;{M}_{*}/{M}_{\\odot }={10.59}_{-0.05}^{+0.04}</script></span></span> (corrected for lensing), and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn87.gif\" alt=\"${A}_{V}={0.2}_{-0.20}^{+0.26}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{A}_{V}={0.2}_{-0.20}^{+0.26}</script></span></span>. This galaxy appears post-starburst, and is striking in that even at <em>z</em> = 2.8, intermediate-mass galaxies with quiescent stellar populations exist.</p><div tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"apj522770t1\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\"><p><b>Table 1.</b>\u00a0\nStellar Population Synthesis Properties\n</p><table cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" align=\"center\">\u00a0</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody></table><p><small>\n<p><strong>Notes.</strong></p>\n<a name=\"apj522770fn1\" id=\"apj522770fn1\"></a><sup> a</sup>This is from the 30-band SED fit with a <em>\u03c4</em>-model star formation history, and is effectively a UV-dust-corrected SFR.\n<a name=\"apj522770fn2\" id=\"apj522770fn2\"></a><sup> b</sup>FAST output before adjusting for lensing magnification\n<p>The best-fit FAST parameters and their values within 68% confidence intervals, adjusted for the lensing magnification (where appropriate) from Muzzin et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib36\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib36\">2012</a>).</p>\n</small></p><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n\t\t\tDownload table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-ascii\" href=\"/0004-637X/819/1/74/suppdata/apj522770t1_ascii.txt?doi=10.3847/0004-637X/819/1/74\" target=\"_blank\">ASCII</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0004-637X/819/1/74/suppdata/apj522770t1_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Typeset image</a></span></p></div><p>Muzzin et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib38\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib38\">2013b</a>) suggests that the quenched fraction for galaxies of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn100.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\;{M}_{*}/{M}_{\\odot }\\gt 10.8$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\;{M}_{*}/{M}_{\\odot }\\gt 10.8</script></span></span> is <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn101.gif\" alt=\"$\\sim 20\\%$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\sim 20\\%</script></span></span> at these redshifts. The identification of galaxies with quiescent populations in Muzzin et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib38\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib38\">2013b</a>) is based on rest-frame color selection and <em>z</em><sub>phot</sub>. Here we confirm unambiguously through spectroscopy that these galaxies do exist at these redshifts.</p><p>Compared to the values of <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib36\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib36\">M12</a>, the effects of fitting the spectrum and photometry with the spectroscopic redshift result in a best fit where the age changes from <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn102.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\;\\mathrm{Age}{\\mathrm{years}}^{-1}={9.0}_{-0.2}^{+0.2}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\;\\mathrm{Age}{\\mathrm{years}}^{-1}={9.0}_{-0.2}^{+0.2}</script></span></span> to <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn103.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\;\\mathrm{Age}\\;{\\mathrm{years}}^{-1}={8.75}_{-0.07}^{+0.07}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\;\\mathrm{Age}\\;{\\mathrm{years}}^{-1}={8.75}_{-0.07}^{+0.07}</script></span></span>, stellar-mass from <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn104.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\;{M}_{*}/{M}_{\\odot }={10.82}_{-0.07}^{+0.05}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\;{M}_{*}/{M}_{\\odot }={10.82}_{-0.07}^{+0.05}</script></span></span> to <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn105.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\;{M}_{*}/{M}_{\\odot }={10.59}_{-0.05}^{+0.04}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\;{M}_{*}/{M}_{\\odot }={10.59}_{-0.05}^{+0.04}</script></span></span>, and dust from <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn106.gif\" alt=\"${A}_{V}={0.9}_{-0.6}^{+0.2}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{A}_{V}={0.9}_{-0.6}^{+0.2}</script></span></span> to <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn107.gif\" alt=\"${A}_{V}={0.2}_{-0.20}^{+0.26}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{A}_{V}={0.2}_{-0.20}^{+0.26}</script></span></span>. It is important to note that these values do not agree (within the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn108.gif\" alt=\"$1\\sigma $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">1\\sigma</script></span></span> errors) with the values reported by <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib36\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib36\">M12</a>. However <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib36\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib36\">M12</a> underestimated the uncertainties associated with the <em>z</em><sub>phot</sub>, leaving a deficit in the error budget resulting in a disagreement of values. With the addition of a <em>z</em><sub>spec</sub>, the best-fit galaxy is younger, less massive, and contains less dust than previously determined by <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib36\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib36\">M12</a>.</p><p>In order to understand the differences in best-fit stellar population parameters between <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib36\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib36\">M12</a> and the present study, we re-fit the data using the photometry and the spectroscopic redshift (omitting the spectra). This produced a different set of parameters from our best fit that is closer to the age, mass, and dust content of <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib36\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib36\">M12</a>, suggesting that the spectrum does drive the fit. We conclude that both the spectroscopic redshift and the spectrum itself, which shows strong Balmer absorption, drive the changes in the stellar populations.</p><p>We note that in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f4\">4</a>, it is clear that our best fit to the photometry and spectroscopy is not ideal. The most striking mismatch occurs in the IRAC bands. The disagreement between the spectrum and photometry in the far-infrared could be attributed to the challenges associated with de-blending the source from the lens, and the lens images from one another. In the IRAC bands, the FWHM of the PSF becomes comparable to the separation between source galaxies and the lens which is 2'' for this system. Accurately separating the flux becomes more difficult than in the observed optical and NIR where the PSF is smaller. We ascertained the effect of the IRAC bands on the fit by re-fitting the spectrum and photometry without IRAC. We found the stellar population parameters to be the same within <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn109.gif\" alt=\"$1\\sigma $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">1\\sigma</script></span></span> and conclude that the IRAC bands do not strongly influence the outcome of the fitting. The current analysis now includes age sensitive absorption features (see below), as well as the new spectroscopic redshift, and therefore we are confident in the stellar population parameters and associated uncertainties determined in this study.</p><p>In Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f5\">5</a>, we find a weak or absent Ca K absorption in the data, whereas the model suggests a stronger absorption line. The observed wavelength of Ca K at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a02.756 is 4780 \u00c5 which overlaps with a strong sky-line at 14793 \u00c5 leading to poor spectral extraction in that region. Thus, the mismatch between the data and model Ca K absorption strength is likely caused by poor data quality in that region. We note that regions affected by strong skylines have larger errors, and will therefore have lower weight in the full spectral fitting</p><p>In addition to the stellar population parameters fit with FAST, we measured the Lick index <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn110.gif\" alt=\"$H{\\delta }_{A}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">H{\\delta }_{A}</script></span></span> (Worthey &amp; Ottaviani <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib75\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib75\">1997</a>) and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn111.gif\" alt=\"${D}_{n}(4000)$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{D}_{n}(4000)</script></span></span> (Balogh et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib2\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib2\">1999</a>) break, which are features shown to be sensitive to age (Kauffmann et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib30\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib30\">2003</a>). With an <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn112.gif\" alt=\"$H{\\delta }_{A}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">H{\\delta }_{A}</script></span></span> measurement from our spectrum, as well as coverage of the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn113.gif\" alt=\"$4000\\;\\mathring{\\rm A} $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">4000\\;\\mathring{\\rm A}</script></span></span> break (as seen by the blue horizontal bars in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f5\">5</a>), we are able to independently verify our model age determination. This independent age verification from the absorption features is important because of inherent degeneracies in fitting the SED. In Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f6\">6</a>, we have plotted <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn114.gif\" alt=\"$H{\\delta }_{A}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">H{\\delta }_{A}</script></span></span> as a function of the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn115.gif\" alt=\"${D}_{n}(4000)$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{D}_{n}(4000)</script></span></span> of our object, as well as a random sample of SDSS galaxies which contain both star-forming and quiescent galaxies.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj522770f6\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj522770f6\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770f6_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 6.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 6.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770f6_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 6.</strong>\u00a0\n<span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn116.gif\" alt=\"$H{\\delta }_{A}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">H{\\delta }_{A}</script></span></span> as a function of <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn117.gif\" alt=\"${D}_{n}(4000)$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{D}_{n}(4000)</script></span></span>. Gray points are a random sample of SDSS galaxies. The orange star is the measurement from the H-band spectroscopy. The solid, colored lines are different Bruzual &amp; Charlot (<a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib11\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib11\">2003</a>) models with different SFH (burst, delayed exponential and constant) with the best-fit values from Table <a class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj522770t1\">1</a> used as inputs. Different benchmark ages are indicated along each track with a triangle (<span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn118.gif\" alt=\"$0.1\\;\\mathrm{Gyr}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">0.1\\;\\mathrm{Gyr}</script></span></span>), circle (<span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn119.gif\" alt=\"$1.0\\;\\mathrm{Gyr}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">1.0\\;\\mathrm{Gyr}</script></span></span>), square (<span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn120.gif\" alt=\"$3.0\\;\\mathrm{Gyr}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">3.0\\;\\mathrm{Gyr}</script></span></span>), and hexagon (<span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn121.gif\" alt=\"$10.0\\;\\mathrm{Gyr}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">10.0\\;\\mathrm{Gyr}</script></span></span>). Marked on the delayed exponential SFH track (the model of choice from FAST), the best-fit age is indicated (red diamond). The close separation reaffirms our age determination.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj522770f6\" href=\"/0004-637X/819/1/74/downloadFigure/figure/apj522770f6\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj522770f6\" href=\"/0004-637X/819/1/74/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj522770f6\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p>Over-plotted in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f6\">6</a> are three different model tracks generated using GALAXEV (Bruzual &amp; Charlot <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib11\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib11\">2003</a>). The best-fit super-solar metallicity of <em>Z</em> = 0.05 from FAST was used in each model track. Two fiducial models (a burst, and constant star formation history) are plotted in blue and magenta to highlight the extremes in the parameter space. A model with a delayed exponential SFH is also plotted in red, using the best-fit parameters from Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj522770t1\">1</a>. The red point corresponds to the age of our best fit using FAST. The separation between the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn122.gif\" alt=\"$H{\\delta }_{A}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">H{\\delta }_{A}</script></span></span> versus <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn123.gif\" alt=\"${D}_{n}(4000)$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{D}_{n}(4000)</script></span></span> determined age and FAST modeled best-fit age is small, confirming the FAST best-fit age in a model independent way. Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f6\">6</a> also shows very little difference in the <em>\u03c4</em> versus delayed-<em>\u03c4</em> models, and that the star formation history is dominated by a population which is consistent with a single burst. From Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f6\">6</a>, we confirm that this galaxy is indeed relatively young, post-starburst, and consistent with being recently quenched.</p></div><h3 id=\"apj522770s3-3\" name=\"apj522770s3-3\">3.3.\u00a0MIPS <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn124.gif\" alt=\"$24\\;\\mu {\\rm{m}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">24\\;\\mu {\\rm{m}}</script></span></span> Photometry</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>As described in Section 5.3 of <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib36\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib36\">M12</a>, there is corresponding MIPS <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn125.gif\" alt=\"$24\\;\\mu {\\rm{m}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">24\\;\\mu {\\rm{m}}</script></span></span> data which was remarked upon. We briefly summarize their findings. They detected observed-frame <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn126.gif\" alt=\"$24\\;\\mu {\\rm{m}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">24\\;\\mu {\\rm{m}}</script></span></span> emission at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn127.gif\" alt=\"$4\\sigma $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">4\\sigma</script></span></span> in the vicinity of the lens system. However, they found the MIPS source to be offset to the south-west by several arcseconds, which suggests that the lens system is not the correct counterpart. Under the possibility that the MIPS detection is coincident with the lens-source system, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib36\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib36\">M12</a> determined an estimate of the sSFR. Since the FWHM of the PSF is <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn128.gif\" alt=\"$5\\buildrel{\\prime\\prime}\\over{.} 5$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">5\\buildrel{\\prime\\prime}\\over{.} 5</script></span></span>, individual sources could not be resolved in MIPS. Photometry was therefore performed in a 7'' aperture which surrounded the entire lens system. For the source and lens, at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn129.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{\\mathrm{phot}}=2.4$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{\\mathrm{phot}}=2.4</script></span></span>, they find <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn130.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\;\\mathrm{sSFR}=-{9.93}_{-0.20}^{+0.20}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\;\\mathrm{sSFR}=-{9.93}_{-0.20}^{+0.20}</script></span></span> which is below the star-forming main sequence for their derived stellar mass at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn131.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{\\mathrm{phot}}=2.4$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{\\mathrm{phot}}=2.4</script></span></span>. Thus, even in the scenario where all of the MIPS emission is associated with the lensed galaxies, they would still be classified as quiescent.</p><p>The new <em>z</em><sub>spec</sub> determination will effect the sSFR found by <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib36\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib36\">M12</a>, which we re-calculate below. We follow the same procedure to find a total un-lensed mass of the source galaxies of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn132.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\;{M}_{*}/{M}_{\\odot }={11.56}_{-0.04}^{+0.08}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\;{M}_{*}/{M}_{\\odot }={11.56}_{-0.04}^{+0.08}</script></span></span>. With the photometry from <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib36\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib36\">M12</a>, and the templates of Dale &amp; Helou (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib21\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib21\">2002</a>), the implied un-lensed SFR is <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn133.gif\" alt=\"${370}_{-83}^{+96}\\;{M}_{\\odot }\\;{\\mathrm{yr}}^{-1}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{370}_{-83}^{+96}\\;{M}_{\\odot }\\;{\\mathrm{yr}}^{-1}</script></span></span>. This yields a <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn134.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\;\\mathrm{sSFR}=-{8.99}_{-0.12}^{+0.12}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\;\\mathrm{sSFR}=-{8.99}_{-0.12}^{+0.12}</script></span></span>. The sSFR of a star-forming main-sequence galaxy is <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn135.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\;\\mathrm{sSFR}\\sim -8.6$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\;\\mathrm{sSFR}\\sim -8.6</script></span></span> for <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn136.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\;{M}_{*}/{M}_{\\odot }=10.59$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\;{M}_{*}/{M}_{\\odot }=10.59</script></span></span> between <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn137.gif\" alt=\"$2.5\\lt z\\lt 3.5$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">2.5\\lt z\\lt 3.5</script></span></span> (Schreiber et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib46\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib46\">2015</a>). This implies that if the MIPS detection is associate with the lensed system, then this galaxy is only 0.3 dex below the star-forming main sequence. We find this implied level of star formation unlikely for two reasons. The first is that the MIPS and NIR sources are offset from one another, and the MIPS detection is not likely associated. The second is our model independent age determination via the strengths of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn138.gif\" alt=\"$H{\\delta }_{A}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">H{\\delta }_{A}</script></span></span> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn139.gif\" alt=\"${D}_{n}(4000)$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{D}_{n}(4000)</script></span></span> (as seen in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f6\">6</a>) which emphasize an older age for the majority of the stars in this galaxy.</p><p>If the MIPS detection were coincident then all star formation would need to be dust-enshrouded, and very recent, so that no young stars are visible outside the birth-clouds. An alternative explanation is that the lens-source system could host an AGN, but we do not see emission lines in the near-IR or optical. Additionally, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib36\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib36\">M12</a> looked for X-ray and radio detections in <em>XMM-Newton</em> and the Very Large Array observations of the COSMOS field and found no detection in the vicinity of the system.</p></div><h3 id=\"apj522770s3-4\" name=\"apj522770s3-4\">3.4.\u00a0Stellar Velocity Dispersion</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>The presence of strong absorption features provide us with the means to study the kinematics of this galaxy, and determine a stellar velocity dispersion. With this measurement, we are able to calculate the dynamical mass and place strong constraints on the baryonic contribution to the total mass budget. Although random errors on broadband photometry can be quite low with state-of-the-art instruments, systematic uncertainties in mass determinations are difficult to estimate accurately (Conroy et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib19\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib19\">2009</a>). Thus, velocity dispersions are key for placing upper limits on the total mass of the system, and hence validating stellar mass estimates.</p><p>A stellar velocity dispersion was estimated using Penalized Pixel-Fitting (pPXF; Cappellari &amp; Emsellem <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib16\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib16\">2004</a>). The spectrum was first resampled onto a logarithmic wavelength scale without interpolation, but with the masking of bad pixels. Template mismatch was accounted for by simultaneously fitting the continuum of the best-fit Bruzual &amp; Charlot (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib11\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib11\">2003</a>) template with an additive polynomial, following the same analysis presented in Appendix 3 of van de Sande et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib60\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib60\">2013</a>).</p><p>The effect of template choice can greatly affect the fitted velocity dispersion.
