We investigated the effect of template choice on the best-fit stellar velocity dispersion, in a similar manner to van de Sande et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib60\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib60\">2013</a>). We fit the spectrum and photometry using FAST with a range of templates for a grid of fixed metallicity and ages. The allowable metallicities were <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn140.gif\" alt=\"$Z=0.004$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">Z=0.004</script></span></span> (super sub-solar), 0.008 (sub-solar), 0.02 (solar) and 0.05 (super-solar). The age range considered was <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn141.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\;\\mathrm{Age}\\;{\\mathrm{years}}^{-1}\\quad =$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\;\\mathrm{Age}\\;{\\mathrm{years}}^{-1}\\quad =</script></span></span> 8.0\u20139.5 in increments of 0.1 dex. We increased the resolution of the age grid to 0.05 dex between <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn142.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\;\\mathrm{Age}\\;{\\mathrm{years}}^{-1}\\quad =$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\;\\mathrm{Age}\\;{\\mathrm{years}}^{-1}\\quad =</script></span></span> 8.6\u20138.9, as we found in previous fitting iterations that the FAST estimated <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn143.gif\" alt=\"$1\\sigma $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">1\\sigma</script></span></span>-error was smaller than 0.1 dex.</p><p>In Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f7\">7</a>, we show the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn144.gif\" alt=\"${\\chi }_{\\mathrm{red}}^{2}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\chi }_{\\mathrm{red}}^{2}</script></span></span> from FAST as a function of the best-fit pPXF stellar velocity dispersion (corrected for template, <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn145.gif\" alt=\"$\\sigma =89\\;\\mathrm{km}\\;{{\\rm{s}}}^{-1}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\sigma =89\\;\\mathrm{km}\\;{{\\rm{s}}}^{-1}</script></span></span>, and instrument, <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn146.gif\" alt=\"$\\sigma =25\\;\\mathrm{km}\\;{{\\rm{s}}}^{-1}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\sigma =25\\;\\mathrm{km}\\;{{\\rm{s}}}^{-1}</script></span></span>, resolution). Using Monte-Carlo simulated errors, we determined 1 and 2 sigma limits on the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn147.gif\" alt=\"${\\chi }_{\\mathrm{red}}^{2}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\chi }_{\\mathrm{red}}^{2}</script></span></span> value of the best-fit FAST model (horizontal black dashed lines in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f7\">7</a>). Points that fall below this line are statistically indistinguishable. We find a very narrow range of statistically indistinguishable templates, concluding that our error will be dominated by the formal errors of the fit, and not the template choice.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj522770f7\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj522770f7\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770f7_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 7.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 7.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770f7_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 7.</strong>\u00a0The pPXF best-fit stellar velocity dispersion plotted against the <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn148.gif\" alt=\"${\\chi }_{\\mathrm{red}}^{2}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\chi }_{\\mathrm{red}}^{2}</script></span></span> output from FAST fitting both the spectrum and the photometry. Each point represents a different age (from <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn149.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\;\\mathrm{Age}\\;{\\mathrm{years}}^{-1}\\quad =$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\;\\mathrm{Age}\\;{\\mathrm{years}}^{-1}\\quad =</script></span></span> 8.0\u20139.5), and each colored \"track\" a different metallicity. The horizontal dashed black lines are the <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn150.gif\" alt=\"$1\\sigma $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">1\\sigma</script></span></span> and <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn151.gif\" alt=\"$2\\sigma $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">2\\sigma</script></span></span> upper bounds from the Monte Carlo modeling of the best-fit template at <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn152.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\;\\mathrm{Age}\\;{\\mathrm{years}}^{-1}=8.75$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\;\\mathrm{Age}\\;{\\mathrm{years}}^{-1}=8.75</script></span></span>. Points below these lines indicate templates that are statistically indistinguishable from each other. There are only three of these points, and they result in a stable stellar velocity dispersion implying that template choice is not the dominant source of uncertainty.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj522770f7\" href=\"/0004-637X/819/1/74/downloadFigure/figure/apj522770f7\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj522770f7\" href=\"/0004-637X/819/1/74/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj522770f7\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p>Accounting for instrumental and template resolution, as well as a rectangular aperture and seeing (see van de Sande et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib60\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib60\">2013</a>), we find a best-fit pPXF stellar velocity dispersion of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn153.gif\" alt=\"$\\sigma =187\\pm 43\\;\\mathrm{km}\\;{{\\rm{s}}}^{-1}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\sigma =187\\pm 43\\;\\mathrm{km}\\;{{\\rm{s}}}^{-1}</script></span></span> (the error is the 68% confidence limits from the Monte-Carlo simulations).</p><p>From the assumption that the galaxy is virialized, we can determine the dynamical mass as follows:</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj522770eqn2\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770eqn2.gif\" alt=\"Equation (2)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{M}_{\\mathrm{dyn}}=\\displaystyle \\frac{\\beta (n){\\sigma }_{{\\rm{e}}}^{2}{r}_{{\\rm{e}}}}{G}.\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t2\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>Here <em>G</em> is the gravitational constant, and <em>\u03b2</em> is an expression as a function of the S\u00e9rsic index, <em>n</em>, from Cappellari et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib15\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib15\">2006</a>, their Equation (20)):</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj522770eqn3\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770eqn3.gif\" alt=\"Equation (3)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&\\beta (n)=8.87-0.831n+0.0241{n}^{2}.\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t3\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>\n</p><p>With <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn154.gif\" alt=\"${r}_{{\\rm{e}}}={0.86}_{-0.14}^{+0.19}\\;\\mathrm{kpc}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{r}_{{\\rm{e}}}={0.86}_{-0.14}^{+0.19}\\;\\mathrm{kpc}</script></span></span> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn155.gif\" alt=\"${3.50}_{-0.60}^{+0.68}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{3.50}_{-0.60}^{+0.68}</script></span></span> from Muzzin et al. (2016, in preparation), the dynamical mass is <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn156.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\;{M}_{\\mathrm{dyn}}/{M}_{\\odot }\\quad ={10.65}_{-0.23}^{+0.18}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\;{M}_{\\mathrm{dyn}}/{M}_{\\odot }\\quad ={10.65}_{-0.23}^{+0.18}</script></span></span> which is quite similar to, but slightly above the derived stellar mass of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn157.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\;{M}_{*}/{M}_{\\odot }={10.59}_{-0.05}^{+0.04}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\;{M}_{*}/{M}_{\\odot }={10.59}_{-0.05}^{+0.04}</script></span></span>.</p><p>Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f8\">8</a> shows <em>r</em><sub>e</sub> as a function of stellar and dynamical mass for high and low-<em>z</em> galaxies with measured stellar velocity dispersions. Also included in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f8\">8</a> is the quiescent galaxy mass\u2013size relation for <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn158.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 0$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 0</script></span></span> (dashed black line). In both stellar and dynamical mass we see that our galaxy is smaller than <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn159.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 0$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 0</script></span></span> galaxies at equivalent mass, and consistent with the higher-redshift quiescent population. This galaxy is indeed compact, which is well established for quiescent galaxies at these redshifts (see Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj522770s1\">1</a> and references therein).</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj522770f8\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj522770f8\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770f8_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 8.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 8.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770f8_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 8.</strong>\u00a0Left: the dynamical mass (<em>M</em><sub>dyn</sub>) vs. <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn160.gif\" alt=\"${r}_{{\\rm{e}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{r}_{{\\rm{e}}}</script></span></span> of the object of this study (orange star) plotted along side other high-redshift objects compiled from van de Sande et al. (<a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib58\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib58\">2015</a>) where the colored symbols follow the same conventions as the legend in Figure <a href=\"#apj522770f2\">2</a>. The dashed black line is the parameterized mass\u2013size relation of SDSS <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn161.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 0$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 0</script></span></span> quiescent galaxies, with the best-fit parameters from van de Sande et al. (<a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib59\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib59\">2011</a>). Right: the same as the left plot, but with stellar mass instead of dynamical mass. In both instances, our object falls below the mass\u2013size relation of <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn162.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 0$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 0</script></span></span> quiescent galaxies confirming compactness out to lower masses at high redshift.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj522770f8\" href=\"/0004-637X/819/1/74/downloadFigure/figure/apj522770f8\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj522770f8\" href=\"/0004-637X/819/1/74/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj522770f8\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p>Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f9\">9</a> shows the comparison between the FAST determined <em>M</em><sub>*</sub>, and the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn163.gif\" alt=\"${M}_{\\mathrm{dyn}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{M}_{\\mathrm{dyn}}</script></span></span>. The black dashed line in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f9\">9</a> is unity\u2014above this line is an \"unphysical\" regime where the stellar mass exceeds the dynamical mass. From this figure, we see that the implied dark matter fraction appears to be very low, at least in the central regions of the galaxy where the bulk of the light is found (Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f8\">8</a>). However the error bars are large, and a dark matter fraction of 50% is also consistent with the data, therefore a definitive conclusion can not be drawn.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj522770f9\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj522770f9\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770f9_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 9.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 9.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770f9_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 9.</strong>\u00a0Dynamical (<em>M</em><sub>dyn</sub>) vs. the stellar (<span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn164.gif\" alt=\"${M}_{*}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{M}_{*}</script></span></span>) mass of the object of this study (orange star) plotted along side other high-redshift objects compiled from van de Sande et al. (<a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib58\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib58\">2015</a>) where the colored symbols follow the same conventions as the legend in Figure <a href=\"#apj522770f2\">2</a>. The high-<em>z</em> objects are mass and color selected. SDSS galaxies are the gray points (which have been color selected with the same UVJ selection as found in Figure <a href=\"#apj522770f2\">2</a>), and the dashed black line is unity. For our object, the stellar mass and dynamical mass agree well.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj522770f9\" href=\"/0004-637X/819/1/74/downloadFigure/figure/apj522770f9\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj522770f9\" href=\"/0004-637X/819/1/74/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj522770f9\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p>In Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f10\">10</a>, we directly compare the total-to-stellar mass ratio (and thus, the dark matter fraction) as a function of redshift, where the mass fraction approaches unity (also seen in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f9\">9</a>). This figure contains the same literature compilation of high-<em>z</em> quiescent galaxies with velocity dispersion measurements as found in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f2\">2</a>. Of the known objects with a velocity dispersion, ours is at the highest redshift, and one of the lowest total-to-stellar mass ratios. There is also a weak trend, with quiescent galaxies becoming increasingly baryon dominated with redshift. This trend was also noted by van de Sande et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib60\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib60\">2013</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib58\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib58\">2015</a>) whose sample extended out to <em>z</em> = 2.3, however between <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00 and <em>z</em> = 1.6, Belli et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib3\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib3\">2014a</a>) found no statistically significant evolution. This may suggest a rapid evolution between redshift <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn165.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 3$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 3</script></span></span> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn166.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 1.6$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 1.6</script></span></span>. To test this, we compare the average total-to-stellar mass ratio of the SDSS sample to galaxies above redshift <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn167.gif\" alt=\"$z\\gt 1.6$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\gt 1.6</script></span></span>. In Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f10\">10</a>, we have indicated the SDSS median total-to-stellar mass ratio as gray circle. The average for galaxies above <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn168.gif\" alt=\"$z\\gt 1.6$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\gt 1.6</script></span></span> is indicated by the red symbol with the 68% confidence interval. From Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f10\">10</a>, we see that galaxies at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn169.gif\" alt=\"$z\\gt 1.6$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\gt 1.6</script></span></span> do have a lower total-to-stellar mass ratio consistent with the findings of van de Sande et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib60\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib60\">2013</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib58\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib58\">2015</a>), however, the average value for the SDSS galaxies and those above <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn170.gif\" alt=\"$z\\gt 1.6$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\gt 1.6</script></span></span> are not statistically different (i.e., they fall within the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn171.gif\" alt=\"$2.5\\sigma $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">2.5\\sigma</script></span></span> uncertainty).</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj522770f10\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj522770f10\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770f10_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 10.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 10.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770f10_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 10.</strong>\u00a0Redshift vs. ratio of dynamical to stellar masses of the color-selected sample compiled by van de Sande et al. (<a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib58\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib58\">2015</a>), and our object. Gray points are SDSS galaxies following the same color selection. The colored symbols follow the same conventions as the legend in Figure <a href=\"#apj522770f2\">2</a>. The gray circle is the average total-to-stellar mass ratio for SDSS galaxies. We note that the 68% confidence limit for the average total-to-stellar mass ratio for the SDSS galaxies is smaller than the gray symbol. The large red circle is the average total-to-stellar mass ratio for galaxies at <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn172.gif\" alt=\"$z\\gt 1.6$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\gt 1.6</script></span></span> with 68% confidence limits. Our object is the highest redshift for which a dispersion has been measured.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj522770f10\" href=\"/0004-637X/819/1/74/downloadFigure/figure/apj522770f10\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj522770f10\" href=\"/0004-637X/819/1/74/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj522770f10\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure></div><h3 id=\"apj522770s3-5\" name=\"apj522770s3-5\">3.5.\u00a0Mass Fundamental Plane</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>Given a stellar mass, a precisely determined <em>r</em><sub>e</sub>, and our stellar velocity dispersion measurement, we are able to tentatively explore the MFP to <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn173.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 3$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 3</script></span></span>, as well as lower masses. The most salient difference between the FP and MFP with regards to evolution with redshift is the zero-point. Although the zero-point of the traditional luminosity FP is shown to evolve with redshift (e.g., van Dokkum &amp; Franx <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib64\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib64\">1996</a>; van Dokkum et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib65\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib65\">1998</a>; Treu et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib55\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib55\">1999</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib54\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib54\">2001</a>), the MFP does not (Bolton et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib8\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib8\">2008</a>; Holden et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib27\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib27\">2010</a>; Bezanson et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib6\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib6\">2013</a>). The evolution of the zero-point of the FP can be used to investigate the luminosity evolution of quiescent galaxies, whereas the zero-point evolution in the MFP can be used to investigate the corresponding structural and dynamical evolution (Bezanson et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib6\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib6\">2013</a>).</p><p>Strikingly, Bezanson et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib6\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib6\">2013</a>) established that the zero-point of the MFP does not evolve significantly with redshift, in spite of evolution in the structure and size of quiescent galaxies since <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn174.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 2</script></span></span> (see Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj522770s1\">1</a> and references therein). One outstanding question is whether this trend holds to higher redshifts and lower mass. With this data, we are able to explore both issues simultaneously.</p><p>In Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f11\">11</a> we compare our measurement to galaxies at the highest available redshifts which have velocity dispersions. We applied a redshift cut to the literature compilation of van de Sande et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib58\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib58\">2015</a>) of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn175.gif\" alt=\"$z\\gt 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\gt 2</script></span></span>, which left only 5 galaxies (where the highest spectroscopic redshift is <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn176.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{\\mathrm{spec}}=2.636$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{\\mathrm{spec}}=2.636</script></span></span>) for comparison. Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f11\">11</a> shows that, within measurement uncertainty, our galaxy lies on the same MFP as galaxies at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn177.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 2</script></span></span>. This coherence between <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn178.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 2</script></span></span> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn179.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 3$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 3</script></span></span> suggests that the MFP evolves very little between these epochs. Further data at these redshifts are required for a definitive conclusion.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj522770f11\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj522770f11\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770f11_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 11.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 11.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770f11_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 11.</strong>\u00a0The mass fundamental plane for galaxies at redshift <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn180.gif\" alt=\"$z\\gt 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\gt 2</script></span></span>. Symbols are as per the previous figures. The black dashed line is the best-fit mass FP between <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn181.gif\" alt=\"$1.5\\lt z\\lt 2.2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">1.5\\lt z\\lt 2.2</script></span></span> from Bezanson et al. (<a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib6\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib6\">2013</a>). Our galaxy is within the variance of the galaxies at <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn182.gif\" alt=\"$z\\gt 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\gt 2</script></span></span> around the mass fundamental plane suggesting it is in place at lower masses.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj522770f11\" href=\"/0004-637X/819/1/74/downloadFigure/figure/apj522770f11\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj522770f11\" href=\"/0004-637X/819/1/74/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj522770f11\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure></div></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apj522770s4\" name=\"apj522770s4\">4.\u00a0DISCUSSION AND CONCLUSIONS</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>We have obtained an X-Shooter VLT spectrum of the multiply imaged lensed galaxy COSMOS 0050+4901 found serendipitously in the UltraVISTA field. The lensing of this quiescent galaxy was fortunate, providing a detailed, \"sneak-peak\" at the universe during an exciting time. In order to obtain a spectrum with equivalent S/N, without the magnifying effects of gravitational-lensing, 215 hr of integration time on a 10 m class telescope would have been required. The existence of only a handful of gravitationally lensed, quiescent galaxies (Auger et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib1\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib1\">2011</a>; Geier et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib26\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib26\">2013</a>; Newman et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib39\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib39\">2015</a>) highlights the rarity of these objects, and the opportunity they provide to study the high-<em>z</em>, intermediate-mass mass universe preceding the era of <em>JWST</em>.</p><p>At <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn183.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{\\mathrm{spec}}=2.756\\pm 0.001$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{\\mathrm{spec}}=2.756\\pm 0.001</script></span></span>, COSMOS 0050+4901 is one of the highest-redshift quiescent galaxies with a spectroscopic redshift, as well as the highest-redshift galaxy with a measured velocity dispersion (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn184.gif\" alt=\"$\\sigma =187\\pm 43\\;\\mathrm{km}\\;{{\\rm{s}}}^{-1}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\sigma =187\\pm 43\\;\\mathrm{km}\\;{{\\rm{s}}}^{-1}</script></span></span>). With this spectrum we have detected a suite of Balmer lines (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn185.gif\" alt=\"$H\\gamma $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">H\\gamma</script></span></span>, <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn186.gif\" alt=\"$H\\delta $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">H\\delta</script></span></span>), and the CaH and K absorption lines in the observed H band (Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f5\">5</a>). The detection of multiple absorption lines provides tight constraints on <em>z</em><sub>spec</sub>, and is additionally indicative of the presence of older stellar populations. Within the wavelength covered by the spectrum, we find no evidence of emission lines. With our spectrum, the understanding of the stellar populations of this galaxy change from an older (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn187.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\;\\mathrm{Age}\\;{\\mathrm{years}}^{-1}={9.0}_{-0.2}^{+0.2}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\;\\mathrm{Age}\\;{\\mathrm{years}}^{-1}={9.0}_{-0.2}^{+0.2}</script></span></span>), massive (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn188.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\;{M}_{*}/{M}_{\\odot }\\quad ={10.82}_{-0.07}^{+0.05}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\;{M}_{*}/{M}_{\\odot }\\quad ={10.82}_{-0.07}^{+0.05}</script></span></span>), dusty (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn189.gif\" alt=\"${A}_{V}={0.9}_{-0.6}^{+0.2}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{A}_{V}={0.9}_{-0.6}^{+0.2}</script></span></span>) galaxy (as found by <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib36\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib36\">M12</a>) to a younger (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn190.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\;\\mathrm{Age}\\;{\\mathrm{years}}^{-1}={8.75}_{-0.07}^{+0.07}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\;\\mathrm{Age}\\;{\\mathrm{years}}^{-1}={8.75}_{-0.07}^{+0.07}</script></span></span>), post-starburst galaxy of intermediate mass (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn191.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\;{M}_{*}/{M}_{\\odot }={10.59}_{-0.05}^{+0.04}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\;{M}_{*}/{M}_{\\odot }={10.59}_{-0.05}^{+0.04}</script></span></span>).</p><p>This new age determination is supported by spectral diagnostics such as the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn192.gif\" alt=\"${D}_{{\\rm{n}}}(4000)$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{D}_{{\\rm{n}}}(4000)</script></span></span> (Balogh et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib2\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib2\">1999</a>) and the Lick index <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn193.gif\" alt=\"$H{\\delta }_{A}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">H{\\delta }_{A}</script></span></span> (Worthey &amp; Ottaviani <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib75\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib75\">1997</a>), which have been shown to be sensitive to age (Kauffmann et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib30\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib30\">2003</a>). In Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f6\">6</a>, we show how the aforementioned spectral diagnostics reaffirm the younger age determination of this study in a model independent way. Equipped with this best-fit age, the rest-frame optical colors (Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f2\">2</a>), and the SFR from stellar population modeling (Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f4\">4</a>), we confirm that intermediate-mass galaxies that halt in situ star formation are in place by <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn194.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 3$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 3</script></span></span>.</p><p>In addition to the brightening effects of the magnification, the magnifying effects also increase spatial resolution. With this increase in resolution, accurate structural parameters are determined. Muzzin et al. (2016, in preparation) modeled the gravitationally lensed system and determined the magnification, as well as the surface brightness profile, measuring a S\u00e9rsic index of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn195.gif\" alt=\"${3.50}_{-0.60}^{+0.68}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{3.50}_{-0.60}^{+0.68}</script></span></span> and an <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn196.gif\" alt=\"${r}_{{\\rm{e}}}={0.86}_{-0.14}^{+0.19}\\;\\mathrm{kpc}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{r}_{{\\rm{e}}}={0.86}_{-0.14}^{+0.19}\\;\\mathrm{kpc}</script></span></span>. The right-hand panel of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f8\">8</a> shows the precise <em>r</em><sub>e</sub> measurement of Muzzin et al. (2016, in preparation) as a function of the stellar mass. Over-plotted for comparison are a local, and high-redshift sample. Like the high-redshift sample, our object falls below the local size-mass relation (Shen et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib48\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib48\">2003</a>). We confirm, with a high degree of precision, that this galaxy is compact, which is consistent with what is seen for quiescent galaxies at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn197.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 2</script></span></span> (e.g., Daddi et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib20\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib20\">2005</a>; Trujillo et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib56\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib56\">2006</a>; Zirm et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib77\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib77\">2007</a>; van Dokkum et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib66\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib66\">2008</a>; Szomoru et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib52\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib52\">2012</a>).</p><p>Spectroscopy also allows for a kinematic determination of the mass. The measurement of a dynamical mass is important, as it provides a direct, kinematic method of probing the total matter content of a galaxy, without the uncertainties and prior assumptions associated with parameters such as distance measurement, IMF, and dust content (i.e Conroy et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib19\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib19\">2009</a> places the uncertainty associated with stellar mass estimates to be <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn198.gif\" alt=\"$0.6\\;\\mathrm{dex}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">0.6\\;\\mathrm{dex}</script></span></span> at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn199.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 2</script></span></span>). With the dynamical mass we are able to place a strict upper limit on the baryonic contribution to the total mass of the galaxy. In Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f9\">9</a> we compare the two measurements, and find the stellar and dynamical masses to be consistent with each other, although our results suggest either a low dark matter fraction in the inner kpc of the galaxy, where the bulk of the light is found, or perhaps that the stellar mass content is overestimated within the parameters discussed by Conroy et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib19\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib19\">2009</a>; such as assumptions about the IMF, dust content). However, Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f6\">6</a> shows, via the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn200.gif\" alt=\"$H{\\delta }_{A}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">H{\\delta }_{A}</script></span></span> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn201.gif\" alt=\"${D}_{n}4000$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{D}_{n}4000</script></span></span> indices, a model independent estimation of the age of this object. This result implies consistency in the model choice.</p><p>With a kinematic determination of the mass, and accurately measured structural parameters (<em>r</em><sub>e</sub>, and the S\u00e9rsic index <em>n</em>), we are able to place COSMOS\u00a00050+4901 on the MFP (Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f11\">11</a>). It is well established that local, quiescent galaxies fall on a FP described by surface brightness, size and stellar velocity dispersion (Djorgovski &amp; Davis <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib22\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib22\">1987</a>; Dressler et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib24\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib24\">1987</a>), which is tilted with respect to the prediction from virial equilibrium. This tilt does not evolve significantly, but there is an offset in the plane which becomes larger toward higher redshifts (e.g., van Dokkum &amp; Franx <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib64\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib64\">1996</a>; van Dokkum et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib65\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib65\">1998</a>; Treu et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib55\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib55\">1999</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib54\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib54\">2001</a>) as a result of the luminosity evolution of these galaxies with cosmic time. When replacing the surface brightness with stellar mass density (i.e., the MFP), Bezanson et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib6\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib6\">2013</a>) found that this offset does not evolve significantly and these galaxies fall on the same MFP out to <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn202.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 2</script></span></span>. In Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f11\">11</a> we compare the object in this study to the highest redshift galaxies available with a velocity dispersion measurement. We show that out to <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn203.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 3$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 3</script></span></span> quiescent galaxies fall on the same MFP, and that little evolution takes place between <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn204.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 3$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 3</script></span></span> and the present day.</p><p>A dynamical mass additionally enables the investigation of dark-matter content in the central regions of this galaxy. In Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f10\">10</a>, we have plotted the total-to-stellar mass ratio as a function of redshift, which shows evidence of a trend to decreasing values. However this trend is not statistically significant, as the uncertainties on the dynamical mass at high-<em>z</em> are large. More spectra of these types of objects are required to make a statistically significant claim. If this ratio is low, it is what is expected in the case of a gas-rich, major merger (Robertson et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib45\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib45\">2006</a>; Hopkins et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib28\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib28\">2009</a>), which implies that this galaxy could represent the first generation of quiescent galaxies in the hierarchical merging scenario (White &amp; Rees <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib73\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib73\">1978</a>), making this redshift epoch an exciting prospect for study.</p><p>This case study stands as a proof of concept of the utility of lensed, red galaxies in studying the population of passive galaxies down to lower masses as well as to higher redshifts. This paper also illustrates that few rest-frame optical spectra of quiescent galaxies exist beyond <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn205.gif\" alt=\"$z\\gt 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\gt 2</script></span></span>, and even fewer of galaxies at intermediate mass. We stress the need for further spectra of passive galaxies at higher-redshift, as well as to lower masses, as this parameter space is still under-explored.</p></div> <div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>This research has made use of NASA's Astrophysics Data System. The authors also wish to thank the anonymous referee who's suggestions improved the presentation, and overall clarity of this paper.</p></div></div><!-- End article full text -->\n<!-- Start Footnotes -->\n\t<!-- End Footnotes -->\t\n<!-- Start References List -->\n\n<div class=\"reveal-container reveal-closed reveal-plus-icon exp-w-hash references\">\n                <div class=\"replica-h3 bdt-1 id=\"references-wrapper\">\n                    <div class=\"rss-feed__spinner-wrapper\"><span class=\"offscreen-hidden\">Please wait&hellip; references are loading.</span><span\n                            class=\"spinner icon-spinner rss-feed__spinner\"></span></div>\n                </div>\n            </div>\n        <!-- End References List -->\n</div>\n</div>\n            <div class=\"da2                DeferJS(\"https://badge.dimensions.ai/badge.js\");\n\t\t\t</script>\n\t\t<script>\n                DeferJS(\"https://badge.dimensions.ai/badge.js\");\n\t\t\t</script>\n\t\t<script>\n I have amended it to turn of JS on all IE browsers less than 10.\n\t\tThis is due to a function in the iop.jquery.toolbar line 35/36. Uses .remove which is not native js supported in IE9 or lower */\n\t\t/*if('querySelector' in document\n\t\t&& 'localStorage' in window\n\t\t&& 'addEventListener' in window)*/\n\t\t\n\t\t/* This is the updated selector, taken from: https://justmarkup.com/log/2015/02/26/cut-the-mustard-revisited/ */\n\t\tif('visibilityState' in document) {\n\t\t\n\t\t/*! loadJS: load a JS. We are loading this command straight away, before the body loads, so that IF a user has JS enabled, their show hide panels will automatically be closed. */\n\t\t/* If this isn't here, then these panels appear open while the page is loading, then when the js loads at the bottom of the page, they are shut. So the users sees open content, then hidden after a second or 2 when the js is loaded. <main role=\"main\">\n        <!-- Secondary header starts -->\n<div class=\"secondary-header cf\" id=\"wd-secondary-header\">\n    <!-- Branded journal header starts -->\n<div class=\"big-branded\">\n\n    <div class=\"publication-name\" id=\"wd-pub-name\">\n\t<div class=\"publication-title\" itemprop=\"name\" itemid=\"periodical\">\n\t\t\t\t<!-- Journal image link tile starts -->\n<!-- Logo tile starts -->\n<a href=\"/journal/0004-637X\" itemprop=\"url\">\n    <img src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/8febf88b-d09c-11e5-b0b6-759f86a2008e/apj-2016.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The Astrophysical Journal\">\n</a>\n<!-- Logo tile ends -->\n<!-- Journal image link tile ends -->\n</div>\n\t\t</div>\n    <div class=\"partner-logos m-hide\" id=\"wd-partner-logos\">\n            <div class=\"partner-logo-alignment\">\n                <!-- Partner logo tile starts -->\n<a href=\"\" class=\"overlay-launch\">\n    <img border=\"0\" \"Escape\" key on your keyboard.</p>\n        <div class=\"overlay-img\">\n            <a href=\"\">\n                <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/8a2230b8-d09c-11e5-b0b6-759f86a2008e/aas-2018.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The American Astronomical Society, find out more\">\n            </a>\n        </div>\n        <div class=\"overlay-text\">\n            <p>The American Astronomical Society (AAS), established in 1899 and based in Washington, DC, is the major organization of professional astronomers in North America. Its membership of about 7,000 individuals also includes physicists, mathematicians, geologists, engineers, and others whose research and educational interests lie within the broad spectrum of subjects comprising contemporary astronomy. The mission of the AAS is to enhance and share humanity's scientific understanding of the universe.</p> <p><a href=\"https://aas.org/\">https://aas.org/</a></div>\n        <p class=\"ta-c mt-1 mb-2\"><a href=\"\"></a></p>\n    </div>\n</span>\n<!-- Partner logo tile ends -->\n\n<!-- Partner logo tile starts -->\n<a href=\"\" class=\"overlay-launch\">\n    <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/7ebd1b32-0439-11e9-b401-cfe9679c40e3/iop-2016.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The Institute of Physics, find out more\">\n</a>\n<span class=\"overlay-set\">\n    <div class=\"tint-screen\"></div>\n    <div class=\"overlay-panel\">\n        <a title=\"Close\"  class=\"close-icon close-overlay\" tabindex=\"0\" role=\"button\" aria-describedby=\"close-icon-description\"><span class=\"icon-close\"></span></a>\n        <p id=\"close-icon-description\" class=\"offscreen-hidden\">Click here to close this overlay, or press the \"Escape\" key on your keyboard.</p>\n        <div class=\"overlay-img\">\n            <a href=\"\">\n                <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/7ebd1b32-0439-11e9-b401-cfe9679c40e3/iop-2016.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The Institute of Physics, find out more\">\n            </a>\n        </div>\n        <div class=\"overlay-text\">\n            <p>The Institute of Physics (IOP) is a leading scientific society promoting physics and bringing physicists together for the benefit of all. It has a worldwide membership of around 50 000 comprising physicists from all sectors, as well as those with an interest in physics. It works to advance physics research, application and education; and engages with policy makers and the public to develop awareness and understanding of physics. Its publishing company, IOP Publishing, is a world leader in professional scientific communications.</p> <p><a href=\"https://www.iop.org\">https://www.iop.org</a></p></div>\n        <p class=\"ta-c mt-1 mb-2\"><a href=\"\"></a></p>\n    </div>\n</span>\n<!-- Partner logo tile ends -->\n\n<p></p>\n                </div>\n        </div>\n    </div>\n<!-- Branded journal header ends -->\n</div> <!-- end secondary-header -->\n<!-- Secondary header ends --><div class=\"da1-da2\" itemscope=\"\" itemtype=\"http://schema.org/ScholarlyArticle\" id=\"page-content\">\n            <div class=\"da1 ta1 article-head\">\n                <!-- Start Eyebrow block, containing Surtitle and Labels -->\n<div class=\"eyebrow\">\n\t<!-- Start Collection Labels -->\n    <!-- End Collection Labels --> </div>\n<!-- End Eyebrow block -->\n\n<h1 itemprop=\"headline\" class=\"wd-jnl-art-title\">A STELLAR VELOCITY DISPERSION FOR A STRONGLY LENSED, INTERMEDIATE-MASS QUIESCENT GALAXY AT <I>z</I> = 2.8</h1>\n\n<p class=\"mb-0\">\n\t<span data-authors=\"\">\n\t\t<span itemtype=\"http://schema.org/Person\" itemprop=\"author\" class=\"nowrap\"><span itemprop=\"name\">Allison. <span class=\"icon-newtab\">\n            </a></p>\n        </div>\n\n    <!-- End Email Alert -->\n<!-- End Email Alert --><!-- Start Citation Alert Link -->\n                        <p>\n<div class=\"jnl-notifications-wrapper\">\n    <a class=\"wd-jnl-email-alert\" href=\"https://myiopscience.iop.org/signin?origin=a0&return=https%3A%2F%2Fiopscience.iop.org%2Fmyiopscience%2Falerts%2Fsubscribe%3FarticleID%3D0004-637X%2F819%2F1%2F74\"><span\n            class=\"icon-alarm icon-alarm--jhp\"></span>Create citation alert</a>\n</div><!-- End Citation Alert Link -->\n                    </div>\n\t\t</div>\n    </div>\n    <!-- Article information ends -->\n<!-- Start Info top-->\n    <!-- end Info top --><div class=\"article-content\">\n\t<span id=\"articleId\" class=\"hide\">0004-637X/819/1/74</span>\n<!-- Start Abstract -->\n    <h2 id=\"artAbst\" class=\"collapse-blocked\">Abstract</h2>\n        <!-- Start article video abstract -->\n\t<!-- End article video abstract -->\n\t<div class=\"article-text wd-jnl-art-abstract cf\" itemprop=\"description\">\n            <P>Measuring stellar velocity dispersions of quiescent galaxies beyond <IMG ALIGN=\"MIDDLE\" alt=\"$z\\sim 2$\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/apj522770ieqn1.gif\"></IMG> is observationally challenging. Such measurements require near-infrared spectra with a continuum detection of at least moderate signal to noise, often necessitating long integrations. In this paper, we present deep X-Shooter spectroscopy of one of only two known gravitationally lensed massive quiescent galaxies at <IMG ALIGN=\"MIDDLE\" alt=\"$z\\gt 2$\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/apj522770ieqn2.gif\"></IMG>. This galaxy is quadruply imaged, with the brightest images magnified by a factor of ~5. The total exposure time of our data is 9.8 hr on-source; however, the magnification, and the slit placement encompassing two images, provides a total equivalent exposure time of 215 hr. From this deep spectrum we measure a redshift of (<IMG ALIGN=\"MIDDLE\" alt=\"${z}_{\\mathrm{spec}}=2.756\\pm 0.001$\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/apj522770ieqn3.gif\"></IMG>), making this one of the highest redshift quiescent galaxies that is spectroscopically confirmed. We simultaneously fit both the spectroscopic and photometric data to determine stellar population parameters and conclude that this galaxy is relatively young (<IMG ALIGN=\"MIDDLE\" alt=\"${560}_{-80}^{+100}\\;\\mathrm{Myr}$\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/apj522770ieqn4.gif\"></IMG>), of intermediate mass (<IMG ALIGN=\"MIDDLE\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\;{M}_{*}/{M}_{\\odot }={10.59}_{-0.05}^{+0.04}$\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/apj522770ieqn5.gif\"></IMG>), consistent with low dust content (<IMG ALIGN=\"MIDDLE\" alt=\"${A}_{V}={0.20}_{-0.20}^{+0.26}$\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/apj522770ieqn6.gif\"></IMG>), and has quenched only relatively recently. This recent quenching is confirmed by strong Balmer absorption, particularly <IMG ALIGN=\"MIDDLE\" alt=\"$H\\delta $\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/apj522770ieqn7.gif\"></IMG> (<IMG ALIGN=\"MIDDLE\" alt=\"$H{\\delta }_{A}={6.66}_{-0.92}^{+0.96}$\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/apj522770ieqn8.gif\"></IMG>). Remarkably, this proves that at least some intermediate-mass galaxies have already quenched as early as <IMG ALIGN=\"MIDDLE\" alt=\"$z\\sim 2.8$\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/apj522770ieqn9.gif\"></IMG>. Additionally, we have measured a velocity dispersion of (<IMG ALIGN=\"MIDDLE\" alt=\"$\\sigma =187\\pm 43\\;\\mathrm{km}\\;{{\\rm{s}}}^{-1}$\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/apj522770ieqn10.gif\"></IMG>), making this the highest-redshift quiescent galaxy with a dispersion measurement. We confirm that this galaxy falls on the same mass fundamental plane (MFP) as galaxies at <I>z</I>\u00a0=\u00a02.2, consistent with little to no evolution in the MFP up to <I>z</I>\u00a0=\u00a02.8. Overall this galaxy is proof of the existence of intermediate-mass quenched galaxies in the distant universe, and that lensing is a powerful tool for determining their properties with improved accuracy.</P></div>\n    <!-- End abstract -->\n<!-- Start Export citation and abstract tools -->\n\t<p>\n\t\t<small>Export citation and abstract</small>\n\t\t<span class=\"btn-multi-block\">\n\t\t\t<a href=\"/export?articleId=0004-637X/819/1/74&doi=10.3847/0004-637X/819/1/74&exportFormat=iopexport_bib&exportType=abs&navsubmit=Export+abstract\" class=\"btn btn-primary wd-btn-cit-abs-bib\" title=\"Export BibTex\">BibTeX</a>\n\t\t\t<a href=\"/export?articleId=0004-637X/819/1/74&doi=10.3847/0004-637X/819/1/74&exportFormat=iopexport_ris&exportType=abs&navsubmit=Export+abstract\" class=\"btn btn-primary wd-btn-cit-abs-ris\" title=\"Export RIS\">RIS</a>\n\t\t</span>\n\t</p>\n<!-- End Export citation and abstract tools -->\n<!-- Start AAS Related Links -->\n<div class=\"reveal-container reveal-closed reveal-plus-icon bdt-1 mt-2 mb-2 wd-jnl-art-article-aas-related-links\">\n  <div class=\"replica-h3 mt-0\">\n    <a href=\"#\" class=\"reveal-trigger\" data-reveal-label-alt=\"Hide related links\">Related links</a>\n  </div>\n  <div class=\"reveal-content\">\n    <div class=\"article-meta\"> \n      <ul>\n      \t<li><a href=\"http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2016ApJ...819...74H\" target=\"_blank\">NASA ADS Record <span class=\"icon-newtab\"></span></a></li>\n      \t<li><a href=\"http://nedwww.ipac.caltech.edu/cgi-bin/nph-objsearch?refcode=2016ApJ...819...74H&search_type=Search \" target=\"_blank\">NED Objects <span class=\"icon-newtab\"></span></a></li>\n      \t<li><a href=\"http://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-ref?querymethod=bib&simbo=on&bibcode=2016ApJ...819...74H\" target=\"_blank\">Simbad Objects <span class=\"icon-newtab\"></span></a></li>\n      \t<li><a href=\"/journal/0004-637X/page/About%20Related%20Links\" target=\"_blank\">About Related Links</a></li>\n      \t</ul>\n    </div>\n  </div>\n</div>\n<!-- Start info bottom -->\n    <!-- End info bottom -->\n<!-- Start article full text -->\n\t<div xmlns:book=\"http://api.iop.org/Book/1.0/\" itemprop=\"articleBody\" class=\"wd-jnl-art-full-text article-text\">\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apj522770s1\" name=\"apj522770s1\">1.\u00a0INTRODUCTION</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>It is well established that galaxies with evolved stellar populations were already in place when the universe was less than half of its current age (see for example McCracken et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib34\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib34\">2012</a>; Ilbert et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib29\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib29\">2013</a>; Muzzin et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib38\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib38\">2013b</a>). These galaxies were first identified from a population which exhibited red <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn11.gif\" alt=\"${J}_{{\\rm{s}}}-{K}_{{\\rm{s}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{J}_{{\\rm{s}}}-{K}_{{\\rm{s}}}</script></span></span> colors (Franx et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib25\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib25\">2003</a>). These colors were consistent with taking the spectral energy distribution (SED) of an elliptical or dusty star-burst galaxy and red-shifting to <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn12.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 2</script></span></span>, with the degeneracy between the two types of galaxies lifted with the inclusion of IRAC data (Labb\u00e9 et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib33\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib33\">2005</a>; Williams et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib74\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib74\">2009</a>). From the Franx et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib25\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib25\">2003</a>) sample, subsequent spectroscopy later confirmed that a subset of these \"red galaxies\" were indeed quiescent (van Dokkum et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib63\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib63\">2003</a>;
