Kriek et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib31\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib31\">2006</a>), establishing that galaxies with strongly suppressed star formation were present at higher redshifts.</p><p>A comparison of the stellar populations of quiescent galaxies between <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn13.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 2</script></span></span> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn14.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 0$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 0</script></span></span> via their mass-to-light ratios show that the stellar populations in these galaxies are consistent with passive evolution (e.g., van Dokkum et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib65\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib65\">1998</a>; Treu et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib55\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib55\">1999</a>; Bernardi et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib5\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib5\">2003</a>; van Dokkum et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib68\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib68\">2006</a>). Although quiescent, the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn15.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 2</script></span></span> galaxies are strikingly different in their structure compared to present-day ellipticals. At a given mass, their effective radii (<em>r</em><sub>e</sub>) are a factor of ~2\u20134 smaller than at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn16.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 0$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 0</script></span></span> (e.g., Daddi et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib20\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib20\">2005</a>; Trujillo et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib56\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib56\">2006</a>; Zirm et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib77\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib77\">2007</a>; van Dokkum et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib66\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib66\">2008</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib69\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib69\">2010</a>; Szomoru et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib52\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib52\">2012</a>). This difference in <em>r</em><sub>e</sub> between present-day ellipticals and high-redshift galaxies implies a rapid structural evolution between <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn17.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 2</script></span></span> and today. Although these galaxies must grow by a factor of a few in size, their central stellar-velocity dispersions show little evolution (Toft et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib53\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib53\">2012</a>; Bezanson et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib6\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib6\">2013</a>; van de Sande et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib60\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib60\">2013</a>; Belli et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib3\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib3\">2014a</a>) between these redshifts.</p><p>The evolution of stellar populations between redshift <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn18.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 2</script></span></span> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn19.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 0$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 0</script></span></span> is mirrored in the evolution of the zero-point in the fundamental plane (FP). The FP represents a locus of galaxies which occupy a tight plane determined by a galaxy's surface brightness, size and velocity dispersion (Djorgovski &amp; Davis <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib22\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib22\">1987</a>; Dressler et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib24\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib24\">1987</a>). This plane maintains a slight tilt with respect to the expectation from the assumption of virial equilibrium. This tilt is thought to be caused by a deviation from homology (Capelato et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib14\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib14\">1995</a>; Pahre et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib43\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib43\">1995</a>; Busarello et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib12\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib12\">1997</a>), and by variations in the mass-to-light ratio (van Dokkum et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib65\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib65\">1998</a>; Cappellari et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib15\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib15\">2006</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib17\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib17\">2013</a>; Robertson et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib45\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib45\">2006</a>; Bolton et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib7\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib7\">2007</a>).</p><p>When the dependence of the FP on surface brightness is replaced with the average stellar mass density (i.e., the mass fundamental plane; henceforth MFP), the tilt in the FP virtually disappears (Bolton et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib7\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib7\">2007</a>), or is at least shown to be weaker than the tilt in the FP (Bolton et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib8\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib8\">2008</a>; Holden et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib27\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib27\">2010</a>; Bezanson et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib6\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib6\">2013</a>). In contrast to the evolution in the zero-point of the FP (e.g., van de Sande et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib57\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib57\">2014</a>), the MFP zero-point shows very little evolution out to <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn20.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 2</script></span></span> (Bezanson et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib6\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib6\">2013</a>), reminiscent of the lack of evolution in central stellar-velocity dispersion (Toft et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib53\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib53\">2012</a>; Bezanson et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib6\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib6\">2013</a>; Belli et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib3\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib3\">2014a</a>). However the precise evolution depends on assumptions when counting galaxies and how to connect progenitors to their descendants (van de Sande et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib57\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib57\">2014</a>).</p><p>The consistency of the slope of the MFP with that predicted from virial equilibrium points to variations in mass-to-light ratios as the likely cause of the tilt in the FP. The evolution in mass-to-light ratios is driven by either variations in dark matter content, variations in stellar populations, or a combination of both. In the context of MFP evolution at high-<em>z</em>, it is important to note that the sample of Bezanson et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib6\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib6\">2013</a> in the highest redshift bin was restricted to massive galaxies, i.e., <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn21.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\;{M}_{*}/{M}_{\\odot }\\gt 11.0$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\;{M}_{*}/{M}_{\\odot }\\gt 11.0</script></span></span>, leaving the MFP unpopulated below this mass threshold at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn22.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 2</script></span></span>, and due to redshift coverage, at all masses above <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn23.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 2</script></span></span>.</p><p>Although valuable for testing the evolution of the MPF, measuring stellar velocity dispersions of quiescent galaxies beyond <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn24.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 2</script></span></span> has proven technically challenging. At these redshifts their optical absorption lines are redshifted to the near-infrared (NIR) which has a high and variable sky background. In contrast to actively star-forming galaxies, measuring a stellar-velocity dispersion of quiescent galaxies requires a continuum detection, with moderate signal-to-noise ratios (S/N). Because of the long integration times required to achieve the necessary S/N enabling a stellar velocity dispersion measurement, the community has been restricted to observing the brightest galaxies at these redshifts (Onodera et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib41\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib41\">2010</a>; van de Sande et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib59\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib59\">2011</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib60\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib60\">2013</a>; Toft et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib53\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib53\">2012</a>; Bezanson et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib6\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib6\">2013</a>; Belli et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib3\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib3\">2014a</a>), which van de Sande et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib57\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib57\">2014</a>) showed is also biased toward younger post-starburst galaxies.</p><p>In order to probe higher redshifts and/or lower masses, and circumvent the need for long integration times prior to the era of the <em>James Webb Space Telescope</em> (<em>JWST</em>), we aim to take advantage of the brightening and magnifying effects of strong gravitational lensing. This tool has been successfully implemented in studying the properties of distant star-forming galaxies, with higher resolution and better signal-to-noise than normally possible including lyman-break (e.g., Smail et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib49\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib49\">2007</a>), sub-millimetre (e.g., Vieira et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib71\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib71\">2013</a>) and UV-bright galaxies (e.g., Brammer et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib9\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib9\">2012</a>; Sharon et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib47\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib47\">2012</a>; van der Wel et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib62\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib62\">2013</a>). We aim to extend the utility of gravitational lensing to red, quiescent galaxies.</p><p>Lensed, quiescent galaxies at high redshifts (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn25.gif\" alt=\"$z\\gt 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\gt 2</script></span></span>) are comparably more difficult to find than lensed star-forming galaxies for a variety of reasons. First quiescent galaxies show a declining number density with increasing redshift (i.e., Muzzin et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib38\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib38\">2013b</a>). Thus, there are fewer quiescent galaxies to be lensed at high redshift as compared to star-forming galaxies. Second, blue, lensed star-forming galaxies stand out in red, quiescently dominated galaxy clusters, whereas red, lensed galaxies do not. One of the best places to search for lensed galaxies is behind galaxy clusters as they have deep potential wells. As a result of high star formation rates (SFR), SMGs exhaust their gas on relatively short timescales, and are thus extremely rare in local galaxy clusters. Because of SMG rarity in local clusters, the foreground lensing cluster has few sources in the sub-mm images allowing for trivial detection of the lensed SMGs. This is not the case for quiescent galaxies, where the foreground cluster is also NIR bright. Blue, star-forming galaxies are UV-bright, and lensed candidates at redshift ~2 have this emission shifted to the rest-frame optical, making the high-redshift blue galaxies behind clusters optically bright. With the existence of wide and relatively deep optical surveys such as SDSS, there is a wealth of lensed blue galaxies (e.g, Stark et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib50\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib50\">2013</a>), however large area NIR surveys of comparable depth are not available.</p><p>As such, there are only five red, lensed galaxies presented in the literature. Auger et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib1\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib1\">2011</a>) present an intermediate redshift (<em>z</em> = 0.6) lensed candidate which is multiply imaged. Two of the high-redshift (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn26.gif\" alt=\"$z=1.71,2.15$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z=1.71,2.15</script></span></span>) examples in the literature (Geier et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib26\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib26\">2013</a>) are singly imaged, which are more difficult to create lens models for. There are only two examples of multiply imaged red-lenses at high redshift. One, found by Newman et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib39\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib39\">2015</a>), with a spectroscopic redshift of <em>z</em> = 2.636, and the other is the object of this study which was first identified by Muzzin et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib36\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib36\">2012</a>).</p><p>In this paper we present X-Shooter spectroscopy, and a stellar velocity dispersion measurement of COSMOS 0050+4901, a quiescent galaxy found by Muzzin et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib36\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib36\">2012</a>) in the COSMOS/UltraVISTA field (McCracken et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib34\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib34\">2012</a>). With the current data, this is now the highest redshift quiescent galaxy with a stellar velocity dispersion measurement, as well as the least massive quiescent galaxy beyond redshift 2 with a rest-frame optical spectrum.</p><p>We assume a <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn27.gif\" alt=\"${\\rm{\\Lambda }}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\rm{\\Lambda }}</script></span></span>-CDM cosmology (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn28.gif\" alt=\"${H}_{0}=70\\;\\mathrm{km}\\;{{\\rm{s}}}^{-1}\\;{\\mathrm{Mpc}}^{-1}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{H}_{0}=70\\;\\mathrm{km}\\;{{\\rm{s}}}^{-1}\\;{\\mathrm{Mpc}}^{-1}</script></span></span>, <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn29.gif\" alt=\"${{\\rm{\\Omega }}}_{M}=0.3$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{{\\rm{\\Omega }}}_{M}=0.3</script></span></span>, and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn30.gif\" alt=\"${{\\rm{\\Omega }}}_{{\\rm{\\Lambda }}}=0.7$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{{\\rm{\\Omega }}}_{{\\rm{\\Lambda }}}=0.7</script></span></span>), and AB magnitudes.</p></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apj522770s2\" name=\"apj522770s2\">2.\u00a0DATA</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><h3 id=\"apj522770s2-1\" name=\"apj522770s2-1\">2.1.\u00a0COSMOS 0050+4901</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>COSMOS 0050+4901 is a strongly lensed system where the lens is a single galaxy at <em>z</em> = 0.960 found serendipitously in the COSMOS/UltraVISTA field (McCracken et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib34\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib34\">2012</a>) as a group of exceptionally bright, red galaxies. The source is quadruply imaged, with photometric redshifts of <em>z</em> ~ 2.3\u20132.4 (depending on which of the multiple images is analyzed; Muzzin et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib36\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib36\">2012</a>, hereafter <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib36\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib36\">M12</a>). The brightest three images are magnified by a factor of ~5 (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib36\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib36\">M12</a>, Muzzin et al. 2016, in preparation). In Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f1\">1</a> we show a 3-color UltraVISTA J-, H-, and Ks-band image of the lens-source system. Included in this figure is the placement of the slit used for the spectroscopic data (see Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj522770s2-3\">2.3</a>). As illustrated by the slit position shown in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f1\">1</a>, we have obtained spectroscopy of two images, effectively doubling our exposure time. Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f1\">1</a> also qualitatively illustrates the difference in color between the foreground lens and the source images as a result of their differing redshifts.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj522770f1\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj522770f1\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770f1_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 1.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 1.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770f1_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 1.</strong>\u00a0RGB-image using UltraVISTA Ks-, H-, and J-band DR2 images. The source images are labeled A, B, C, and D, and the foreground lens is indicated. The source images are noticeably redder than the lens because of the discordant redshifts (<span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn31.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{\\mathrm{lens}}=0.960$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{\\mathrm{lens}}=0.960</script></span></span> and <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn32.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{\\mathrm{source}}=2.76$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{\\mathrm{source}}=2.76</script></span></span>) which result in the continuum emission from the lens and source galaxies peaking in different bands. The position of the X-Shooter slit on the sky is indicated. Note that the slit was placed such that it falls on galaxies A and B.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj522770f1\" href=\"/0004-637X/819/1/74/downloadFigure/figure/apj522770f1\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj522770f1\" href=\"/0004-637X/819/1/74/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj522770f1\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p>\n<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib36\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib36\">M12</a> performed an initial estimate of the structural properties of the galaxy using the ground-based <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn33.gif\" alt=\"${K}_{s}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{K}_{s}</script></span></span>-band data. Assuming the best photometric redshift at that time, they estimated <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn34.gif\" alt=\"${r}_{{\\rm{e}}}={0.64}_{-0.18}^{+0.08}\\;\\mathrm{kpc}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{r}_{{\\rm{e}}}={0.64}_{-0.18}^{+0.08}\\;\\mathrm{kpc}</script></span></span> and a S\u00e9rsic index of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn35.gif\" alt=\"$n={2.2}_{-0.9}^{+2.3}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">n={2.2}_{-0.9}^{+2.3}</script></span></span>. Recently, we obtained high-resolution HST\u00a0F160W imaging of COSMOS\u00a00050+4901. With the deep HST image and spectroscopic redshift determined in this analysis, A. Muzzin et al. (2016, in preparation) determined a well-constrained lens model, which allowed them to accurately determine the circularized <em>r</em><sub>e</sub> (corrected for magnification) and <em>n</em> to be <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn36.gif\" alt=\"${0.86}_{-0.14}^{+0.19}\\;\\mathrm{kpc}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{0.86}_{-0.14}^{+0.19}\\;\\mathrm{kpc}</script></span></span> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn37.gif\" alt=\"${3.50}_{-0.60}^{+0.68}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{3.50}_{-0.60}^{+0.68}</script></span></span>.</p></div><h3 id=\"apj522770s2-2\" name=\"apj522770s2-2\">2.2.\u00a0Rest-frame UVJ Colors</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>Williams et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib74\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib74\">2009</a>) demonstrate that galaxies display a clear bi-modality in <em>U</em>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>V</em> and <em>V</em>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>J</em> color-space out to <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a02. Galaxies tend to separate into two sequences in color\u2013color space, one consisting primarily of star-forming galaxies, and one primarily consisting of quiescent galaxies. This bi-modality is driven by a galaxy's UV+IR determined SFR. Beyond <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a02, measurement errors, and completeness limits reduces this bi-modailty (Williams et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib74\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib74\">2009</a>; Muzzin et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib38\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib38\">2013b</a>).</p><p>We calculate the rest-frame <em>U</em>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>V</em> and <em>V</em>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>J</em> colors for <em>COSMOS</em>\u00a0 0050+4901 using the photometric data presented in <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib36\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib36\">M12</a> (via <em>EAZY</em>; Brammer et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib10\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib10\">2008</a>). We de-blending the lens from the images, which showed non-negligible contamination in the PSF-matched ground based imaging, by simultaneously fitting both the images and the lens using <em>GALFIT</em> (Peng et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib44\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib44\">2010</a>; further details may be found in <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib36\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib36\">M12</a>).</p><p>In Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f2\">2</a> we show that our object falls on the quiescent region in the <em>UVJ</em> diagram (using <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn38.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{\\mathrm{spec}}=2.756;$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{\\mathrm{spec}}=2.756;</script></span></span> the determination of which is described in Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj522770s3-1\">3.1</a>). We compare and contrast it to a quiescent, spectroscopic sample compilation (from van de Sande et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib58\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib58\">2015</a>), with a redshift distribution of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn39.gif\" alt=\"$0.6\\lt z\\lt 2.2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">0.6\\lt z\\lt 2.2</script></span></span>). This sample contains 63 galaxies at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn40.gif\" alt=\"$0.4\\lt z\\lt 1.6$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">0.4\\lt z\\lt 1.6</script></span></span> from Bezanson et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib6\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib6\">2013</a>), 38 galaxies at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn41.gif\" alt=\"$1\\lt z\\lt 1.4$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">1\\lt z\\lt 1.4</script></span></span> from Belli et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib3\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib3\">2014a</a>), 18 galaxies at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn42.gif\" alt=\"$0.6\\lt z\\lt 1.1$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">0.6\\lt z\\lt 1.1</script></span></span> from van der Wel et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib61\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib61\">2005</a>), 16 galaxies at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn43.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 0.8$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 0.8</script></span></span> from Wuyts et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib76\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib76\">2004</a>), 5 galaxies at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn44.gif\" alt=\"$1.2\\lt z\\lt 1.6$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">1.2\\lt z\\lt 1.6</script></span></span> from Newman et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib40\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib40\">2010</a>), 4 galaxies at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn45.gif\" alt=\"$1.4\\lt z\\lt 2.1$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">1.4\\lt z\\lt 2.1</script></span></span> from van de Sande et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib60\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib60\">2013</a>), 3 galaxies at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn46.gif\" alt=\"$2.1\\lt z\\lt 2.4$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">2.1\\lt z\\lt 2.4</script></span></span> from Belli et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib4\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib4\">2014b</a>), 1 galaxy at <em>z</em> = 2.2 from van Dokkum et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib67\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib67\">2009</a>), 1 galaxy at <em>z</em> = 1.8 from Onodera et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib42\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib42\">2012</a>), and 1 galaxy at <em>z</em> = 2.6 from Newman et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib39\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib39\">2015</a>; see Table in van de Sande et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib58\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib58\">2015</a> for further details). As stated in van de Sande et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib58\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib58\">2015</a>), the sample is selected based on the availability of kinematic measurements in the literature. Thus, this sample is biased toward brighter objects. In Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f2\">2</a> we also indicate the <em>UVJ</em> color selection from van de Sande et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib58\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib58\">2015</a>) as the dashed black line.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj522770f2\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj522770f2\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770f2_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 2.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 2.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770f2_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 2.</strong>\u00a0Rest-frame <em>U</em>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>V</em> color vs. <em>V</em>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>J</em> color. Gray points are a redshift selected (<span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn47.gif\" alt=\"$1.5\\lt z\\lt 2.5$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">1.5\\lt z\\lt 2.5</script></span></span>) comparison sample from the K<sub>s</sub>-band selected UVISTA catalog (McCracken et al. <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib34\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib34\">2012</a>). The black dashed line is the color selection implemented by van de Sande et al. (<a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib58\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib58\">2015</a>) to separate quiescent and star-forming galaxies. Colored points are a high-redshift (<span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn48.gif\" alt=\"$0.6\\lt z\\lt 2.3$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">0.6\\lt z\\lt 2.3</script></span></span>) sample compiled by van de Sande et al. (<a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib58\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib58\">2015</a>), with the literature sources indicated in the plot legend. Our object (orange star) sits on the UVISTA <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn49.gif\" alt=\"$1.5\\lt z\\lt 2.5$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">1.5\\lt z\\lt 2.5</script></span></span> red sequence, and within the locus of other high-redshift, quiescent galaxies with measured stellar velocity dispersions.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj522770f2\" href=\"/0004-637X/819/1/74/downloadFigure/figure/apj522770f2\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj522770f2\" href=\"/0004-637X/819/1/74/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj522770f2\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p>Also plotted in grayscale in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f2\">2</a> is a redshift-selected (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn50.gif\" alt=\"$1.5\\lt z\\lt 2.5$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">1.5\\lt z\\lt 2.5</script></span></span>), photometric sub-sample from the K-band selected catalog of UltraVISTA from Muzzin et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib37\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib37\">2013a</a>; with the limiting magnitude <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn51.gif\" alt=\"$K\\lt 24.4$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">K\\lt 24.4</script></span></span> in a <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn52.gif\" alt=\"$2\\buildrel{\\prime\\prime}\\over{.} 1$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">2\\buildrel{\\prime\\prime}\\over{.} 1</script></span></span> aperture). This sub-sample contains both star-forming, and quiescent galaxies. The redshift range was chosen in order to highlight the color bi-modality, which as previously mentioned, is erased at higher redshifts due to incompleteness and measurement errors. In comparison to both the spectroscopic and photometric samples, our object has colors similar to galaxies with quiescent populations.</p></div><h3 id=\"apj522770s2-3\" name=\"apj522770s2-3\">2.3.\u00a0Spectroscopic Data</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>Data were obtained using the X-Shooter instrument on VLT UT2 (D'Odorico et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib23\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib23\">2006</a>; Vernet et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib70\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib70\">2011</a>) with the K-band blocking filter in place. The target was observed in service mode; the observations were carried out between 2012 December and 2014 February (program Muzzin 090.B-0452(A), and DDT program Muzzin 288.B-5043(A)). All observations had clear sky conditions and an average seeing of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn53.gif\" alt=\"$0\\buildrel{\\prime\\prime}\\over{.} 8$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">0\\buildrel{\\prime\\prime}\\over{.} 8</script></span></span>. A <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn54.gif\" alt=\"$0\\buildrel{\\prime\\prime}\\over{.} 9$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">0\\buildrel{\\prime\\prime}\\over{.} 9</script></span></span> slit was used in the NIR, aligned in the north\u2013south direction with two of the images on the slit, as shown in the UltraVISTA color image in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f1\">1</a>. X-Shooter simultaneously takes spectra in the observed UVB and VIS. The UVB and VIS arm data had no signal, as expected from the very red SED.</p><p>The NIR sky changes on short timescales (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn55.gif\" alt=\"$\\sim \\mathrm{minutes}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\sim \\mathrm{minutes}</script></span></span>) and to compensate for changing sky levels, it is customary to perform a nodding pattern, with two frames adjacent in time subtracted from each other with the object offset in adjacent frames, often referred to as an ABBA observing pattern. Given the size of the X-Shooter slit (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn56.gif\" alt=\"$0\\buildrel{\\prime\\prime}\\over{.} 9\\;$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">0\\buildrel{\\prime\\prime}\\over{.} 9\\;</script></span></span> <b>&#x00d7;</b> 11''), the spatial extent of our object was such that there was insufficient space to perform this nodding pattern with enough empty sky for a successful sky subtraction. As such, observing blocks were 10 minutes, with a nodding pattern offset in declination in <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn57.gif\" alt=\"$0\\buildrel{\\prime\\prime}\\over{.} 4$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">0\\buildrel{\\prime\\prime}\\over{.} 4</script></span></span> increments to a maximum offset of 2'' which corresponds to a shift on the slit of between 2 and 10 pixels. These offsets were made for the identification and removal of bad pixels.</p><p>The images were reduced using the method most commonly used in optical spectroscopy (see Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj522770s2-4\">2.4</a>). Of 64 science frames with 600 s exposure of exposure time on each frame, 5 frames did not contain the target and were thus not used in the final combination (but utilized in sky subtraction\u2014see Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj522770s2-4\">2.4</a>). This results in a science image with a total exposure time of 9.8 hr. However, obtaining a similar S/N spectrum on a single galaxy with comparable un-lensed magnitude (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn58.gif\" alt=\"$K\\sim 22.7$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">K\\sim 22.7</script></span></span>) would require 215 hr when accounting for the fact that our observations are sky-limited, 2 objects fall on the slit and that we are only semi-resolved. This gain in S/N demonstrates the substantial observing advantage provided by strong gravitational lensing. Additionally, a B9V telluric standard star (Hipparcos 049704) was also observed before and after the science target for removal of atmospheric absorption lines, as well as relative flux calibration between orders.</p></div><h3 id=\"apj522770s2-4\" name=\"apj522770s2-4\">2.4.\u00a0Spectroscopic Reduction</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>The data were reduced with the ESO pipeline for X-Shooter (ver 3.10; Modigliani et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib35\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib35\">2010</a>), following the \"physical\" mode reduction chain using EsoRex. Individual frames were reduced in stare mode, as the extent of the object on the slit made standard sky subtraction difficult. Bad-pixel masks were generated using IRAF task <em>ccd</em>_<em>mask</em>, and bad-pixels corrected for using the IRAF task <em>fixpix</em>.</p><p>Because of the methodology of our sky subtraction, we found several detector artefacts on the images which complicated this procedure. In order to subtract these artefacts, we generated a sky frame out of 5 blank sky frames from our observations, as well as other 10 minutes exposures which used the K-band blocking filter found in the X-Shooter archive. We used a total of 28 frames. These frames were all median combined to generate a high S/N sky-frame. This sky-frame was then subtracted from the science frames to subtract the detector artefacts.</p><p>The OH-emission lines in the NIR vary in flux, and change on short timescales, so the sky-frame subtraction could not account for sky lines. To account for this, the sky was modeled along each column in the spatial direction, while masking out rows which contained galaxy flux. This modeled sky was then subtracted from each column. The individual exposures were then median combined order by order.</p><p>The telluric standard spectra were reduced in the same way as the science frames. We constructed a response spectrum from the telluric star, and a black body curve with a <em>T</em><sub>eff</sub> matching a B9V star. Residuals from Balmer absorption in the telluric standard were removed by interpolation. The science observations were corrected for instrumental response and atmospheric absorption by division of the response spectrum.</p><p>To extract the spectrum, a one-dimensional (1D) light profile was fit to each wavelength pixel (or column) along the spatial direction. The light profile was modeled from a median combination of all these fitted profiles from an order in the H band (the highest S/N region of our spectrum). Order number 17 is shown in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f3\">3</a> to illustrate. The light profile found in the top panel of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f3\">3</a> was fit, with a background term, to each column of the combined, two-dimensional (2D) spectrum:</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj522770eqn1\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770eqn1.gif\" alt=\"Equation (1)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{c}_{\\lambda }={a}_{\\lambda }{P}_{y}+{b}_{\\lambda }\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t1\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>\n</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj522770f3\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj522770f3\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770f3_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 3.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 3.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770f3_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 3.</strong>\u00a0Above is an example of our prescription for column rejection and spectral extraction. From to to bottom: (1) The median combined 2D spectrum. (2) The model reconstruction from the double gaussian fitting as described in \"Spectroscopic Reduction.\" (3) The residuals of (1) and (2). (4) The coefficient of the relative strength of the double-peak profile (effectively the extracted 1D spectrum with normalized units). (5) The coefficient of the background term. (6) The relative error error from the fit. The columns are rejected above a specified \"Fit Error\" which varied with each spectral order. The blue shaded regions in (1) and (2) are the columns which are rejected.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj522770f3\" href=\"/0004-637X/819/1/74/downloadFigure/figure/apj522770f3\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj522770f3\" href=\"/0004-637X/819/1/74/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj522770f3\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p><em>\u03bb</em> and <em>y</em> refer to the spatial and spectral dimensions. <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn59.gif\" alt=\"${c}_{\\lambda }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{c}_{\\lambda }</script></span></span> refers to the column, <em>P</em><sub><em>y</em></sub> is the double peaked profile fit to each column, <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn60.gif\" alt=\"${a}_{\\lambda }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{a}_{\\lambda }</script></span></span> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn61.gif\" alt=\"${b}_{\\lambda }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{b}_{\\lambda }</script></span></span> are the fitted coefficients. <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn62.gif\" alt=\"${a}_{\\lambda }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{a}_{\\lambda }</script></span></span> is effectively the 1D spectrum, and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn63.gif\" alt=\"${b}_{\\lambda }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{b}_{\\lambda }</script></span></span> is the background term (see the fourth and fifth panels in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f3\">3</a>). The error spectrum (bottom panel of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f3\">3</a>) is the covariance of the fit, using the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn64.gif\" alt=\"$1\\sigma $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">1\\sigma</script></span></span> value of the pixels at each location. Skylines and bad columns were flagged using an error cutoff (above which the columns would be rejected).</p><p>The low-resolution spectrum was constructed by binning the 1D spectrum in the wavelength direction, using a bi-weight mean (as described in van de Sande et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib60\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib60\">2013</a>) with a bin size of 10 good pixels. We show the spectrum, along with photometry and the best-fit BC03 model in Figures <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f4\">4</a> and <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f5\">5</a>.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj522770f4\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj522770f4\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770f4_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 4.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 4.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770f4_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 4.</strong>\u00a0Best-fit FAST BC03 template (red-line) with photometry (blue points) and H-band X-Shooter spectrum (black-line). Gray regions indicate strong atmospheric absorption resulting in low S/N spectra. The J-band spectrum was omitted due to contamination from the lensing galaxy (see text for further discussion). Best-fit stellar population parameters and their 68% confidence intervals can be found in Table <a class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj522770t1\">1</a>.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj522770f4\" href=\"/0004-637X/819/1/74/downloadFigure/figure/apj522770f4\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj522770f4\" href=\"/0004-637X/819/1/74/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj522770f4\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj522770f5\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj522770f5\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770f5_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 5.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 5.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770f5_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 5.</strong>\u00a0Similar to Figure <a href=\"#apj522770f4\">4</a>, but with the wavelength range restricted to the H band, and the location of prominent absorption lines indicated. The fitted spectrum was smoothed using a bi-weight mean with a bin size of 10 good points (i.e., those that were not rejected by our criteria described in Section <a class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj522770s2-3\">2.3</a>). The spectrum shown above has been smoothed to better illustrate the presence of absorption lines.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj522770f5\" href=\"/0004-637X/819/1/74/downloadFigure/figure/apj522770f5\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj522770f5\" href=\"/0004-637X/819/1/74/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj522770f5\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure></div></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apj522770s3\" name=\"apj522770s3\">3.\u00a0STRUCTURAL PROPERTIES AND STELLAR POPULATIONS</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><h3 id=\"apj522770s3-1\" name=\"apj522770s3-1\">3.1.\u00a0Redshift Determination</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>A spectroscopic redshift was measured using FAST (Kriek et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib32\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib32\">2009</a>), an IDL-based fitting routine which fits stellar population synthesis models to photometry/spectra. This fitting is described in more detail in Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj522770s3-2\">3.2</a>.</p><p>Our best-fit redshift is <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn65.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{\\mathrm{spec}}=2.756\\pm 0.001$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{\\mathrm{spec}}=2.756\\pm 0.001</script></span></span>. This is a high-confidence measurement, as numerous absorption lines, such as <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn66.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{Ca}\\;{\\rm{H}}\\quad \\mathrm{and}\\quad {\\rm{K}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{Ca}\\;{\\rm{H}}\\quad \\mathrm{and}\\quad {\\rm{K}}</script></span></span>, <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn67.gif\" alt=\"$H\\delta $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">H\\delta</script></span></span>, and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn68.gif\" alt=\"$H\\gamma $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">H\\gamma</script></span></span> are detected. Notably, the difference between the photometric (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn69.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{\\mathrm{phot}}=2.4\\pm 0.13$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{\\mathrm{phot}}=2.4\\pm 0.13</script></span></span>) and spectroscopic redshift (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn70.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{\\mathrm{spec}}=2.756\\pm 0.001$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{\\mathrm{spec}}=2.756\\pm 0.001</script></span></span>) is more than twice the uncertainty on the photometric redshift. The possible explanations for this discrepancy are discussed below.</p><p>The difference between the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn71.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{\\mathrm{spec}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{\\mathrm{spec}}</script></span></span> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn72.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{\\mathrm{phot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{\\mathrm{phot}}</script></span></span> might originate from mistaking the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn73.gif\" alt=\"$4000\\;\\mathring{\\rm A} $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">4000\\;\\mathring{\\rm A}</script></span></span> break and Balmer-break. The <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn74.gif\" alt=\"$4000\\;\\mathring{\\rm A} $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">4000\\;\\mathring{\\rm A}</script></span></span> break and Balmer-break (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn75.gif\" alt=\"$\\sim 3640\\;\\mathring{\\rm A} $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\sim 3640\\;\\mathring{\\rm A}</script></span></span>) are two continuum features which are difficult to resolve in photometric data sets due to their proximity in wavelength. Both continuum features result in a color differential between each side of the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn76.gif\" alt=\"$4000\\;\\mathring{\\rm A} $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">4000\\;\\mathring{\\rm A}</script></span></span>/<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn77.gif\" alt=\"$3650\\;\\mathring{\\rm A} $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">3650\\;\\mathring{\\rm A}</script></span></span> spectral region, the strength of which correlates with age in both cases. They do, however, originate from different physical processes, and thus <em>how</em> they correlate with age is different. The <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn78.gif\" alt=\"$4000\\;\\mathring{\\rm A} $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">4000\\;\\mathring{\\rm A}</script></span></span> break is a result of absorption by ionized metals which is strongest in older and high-metallicity stellar populations. The Balmer-break marks the limit of the Balmer series and blending of higher order Balmer lines, and is strongest in A-stars. The strength of the Balmer-break monotonically increases before peaking at intermediate ages (~0.5\u20131 Gyr) when the stellar light is dominated by A-stars.</p><p>Both these features can be prominent in the continuum of quiescent galaxies, and fall into the NIR between <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn79.gif\" alt=\"$1.5\\lt z\\lt 3$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">1.5\\lt z\\lt 3</script></span></span>. The discrepancy between the <em>z</em><sub>phot</sub> and <em>z</em><sub>spec</sub> determination is likely caused by a combination of wavelength gaps between the transmission curves in the NIR bands (J, H, and K<sub>s</sub>), as well as wide bandwidth in the same filters. This results in a <em>J</em>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>H</em> color appropriately explained by either the presence of the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn80.gif\" alt=\"$4000\\;\\mathring{\\rm A} $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">4000\\;\\mathring{\\rm A}</script></span></span> break at lower <em>z</em>, or the Balmer-break at higher <em>z</em>.</p><p>This uncertainty associated with the breaks falling between the NIR filters likely caused the fitting confusion between a quiescent galaxy with a prominent <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn81.gif\" alt=\"$4000\\;\\mathring{\\rm A} $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">4000\\;\\mathring{\\rm A}</script></span></span> break at <em>z</em> = 2.4, and a post-SB galaxy with a <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn82.gif\" alt=\"$3650\\;\\mathring{\\rm A} $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">3650\\;\\mathring{\\rm A}</script></span></span> Balmer-break at <em>z</em> = 2.8. This illustrates the challenges of using <em>z</em><sub>phot</sub> only. This issue is well known, and that even with high S/N NIR photometry, photometric redshifts at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn83.gif\" alt=\"$z\\gt 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\gt 2</script></span></span> can be uncertain due to these issues. This has led to the use of NIR \"medium bands\" as in the NEWFIRM Medium Band Survey (Whitaker et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib72\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib72\">2011</a>) and zFOURGE Survey (Straatman et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib51\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib51\">2014</a>) to provide improved photometric redshifts for galaxies where the Balmer and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn84.gif\" alt=\"$4000\\;\\mathring{\\rm A} $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">4000\\;\\mathring{\\rm A}</script></span></span> breaks fall in the observed NIR.</p><p>This redshift difference is large enough that it changes the stellar population parameters by <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib36\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib36\">M12</a> at a level that is larger than the quoted uncertainties in that paper, particularly the stellar mass, age, and dust content. In the next section we present revised values for these parameters using the spectroscopic redshift.</p></div><h3 id=\"apj522770s3-2\" name=\"apj522770s3-2\">3.2.\u00a0Stellar Population Properties</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>Stellar population properties are estimated using FAST (Kriek et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib32\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib32\">2009</a>). We used Bruzual &amp; Charlot (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib11\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib11\">2003</a>) templates, with a delayed, exponentially declining star formation history (with timescale <em>\u03c4</em>), a Chabrier (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib18\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib18\">2003</a>) IMF, and Calzetti et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib13\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib13\">2000</a>) dust law.</p><p>We have simultaneously fit both the photometry and H-band spectrum. We have omitted the J-band spectrum but include the J-band photometry. The spectrum in the J band is very low S/N as the flux from the lens peaks in the J band (see Figure 4 of <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib36\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib36\">M12</a>). The image and lens are spatially close with contamination affecting the continuum strength. The best fit parameters are summarized in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj522770t1\">1</a>.
