The existence of only a handful of gravitationally lensed, quiescent galaxies (Auger et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib1\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib1\">2011</a>; Geier et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib26\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib26\">2013</a>; Newman et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib39\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib39\">2015</a>) highlights the rarity of these objects, and the opportunity they provide to study the high-<em>z</em>, intermediate-mass mass universe preceding the era of <em>JWST</em>.</p><p>At <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn183.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{\\mathrm{spec}}=2.756\\pm 0.001$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{\\mathrm{spec}}=2.756\\pm 0.001</script></span></span>, COSMOS 0050+4901 is one of the highest-redshift quiescent galaxies with a spectroscopic redshift, as well as the highest-redshift galaxy with a measured velocity dispersion (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn184.gif\" alt=\"$\\sigma =187\\pm 43\\;\\mathrm{km}\\;{{\\rm{s}}}^{-1}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\sigma =187\\pm 43\\;\\mathrm{km}\\;{{\\rm{s}}}^{-1}</script></span></span>). With this spectrum we have detected a suite of Balmer lines (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn185.gif\" alt=\"$H\\gamma $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">H\\gamma</script></span></span>, <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn186.gif\" alt=\"$H\\delta $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">H\\delta</script></span></span>), and the CaH and K absorption lines in the observed H band (Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f5\">5</a>). The detection of multiple absorption lines provides tight constraints on <em>z</em><sub>spec</sub>, and is additionally indicative of the presence of older stellar populations. Within the wavelength covered by the spectrum, we find no evidence of emission lines. With our spectrum, the understanding of the stellar populations of this galaxy change from an older (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn187.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\;\\mathrm{Age}\\;{\\mathrm{years}}^{-1}={9.0}_{-0.2}^{+0.2}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\;\\mathrm{Age}\\;{\\mathrm{years}}^{-1}={9.0}_{-0.2}^{+0.2}</script></span></span>), massive (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn188.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\;{M}_{*}/{M}_{\\odot }\\quad ={10.82}_{-0.07}^{+0.05}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\;{M}_{*}/{M}_{\\odot }\\quad ={10.82}_{-0.07}^{+0.05}</script></span></span>), dusty (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn189.gif\" alt=\"${A}_{V}={0.9}_{-0.6}^{+0.2}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{A}_{V}={0.9}_{-0.6}^{+0.2}</script></span></span>) galaxy (as found by <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib36\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib36\">M12</a>) to a younger (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn190.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\;\\mathrm{Age}\\;{\\mathrm{years}}^{-1}={8.75}_{-0.07}^{+0.07}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\;\\mathrm{Age}\\;{\\mathrm{years}}^{-1}={8.75}_{-0.07}^{+0.07}</script></span></span>), post-starburst galaxy of intermediate mass (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn191.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}\\;{M}_{*}/{M}_{\\odot }={10.59}_{-0.05}^{+0.04}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}\\;{M}_{*}/{M}_{\\odot }={10.59}_{-0.05}^{+0.04}</script></span></span>).</p><p>This new age determination is supported by spectral diagnostics such as the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn192.gif\" alt=\"${D}_{{\\rm{n}}}(4000)$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{D}_{{\\rm{n}}}(4000)</script></span></span> (Balogh et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib2\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib2\">1999</a>) and the Lick index <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn193.gif\" alt=\"$H{\\delta }_{A}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">H{\\delta }_{A}</script></span></span> (Worthey &amp; Ottaviani <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib75\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib75\">1997</a>), which have been shown to be sensitive to age (Kauffmann et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib30\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib30\">2003</a>). In Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f6\">6</a>, we show how the aforementioned spectral diagnostics reaffirm the younger age determination of this study in a model independent way. Equipped with this best-fit age, the rest-frame optical colors (Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f2\">2</a>), and the SFR from stellar population modeling (Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f4\">4</a>), we confirm that intermediate-mass galaxies that halt in situ star formation are in place by <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn194.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 3$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 3</script></span></span>.</p><p>In addition to the brightening effects of the magnification, the magnifying effects also increase spatial resolution. With this increase in resolution, accurate structural parameters are determined. Muzzin et al. (2016, in preparation) modeled the gravitationally lensed system and determined the magnification, as well as the surface brightness profile, measuring a S\u00e9rsic index of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn195.gif\" alt=\"${3.50}_{-0.60}^{+0.68}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{3.50}_{-0.60}^{+0.68}</script></span></span> and an <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn196.gif\" alt=\"${r}_{{\\rm{e}}}={0.86}_{-0.14}^{+0.19}\\;\\mathrm{kpc}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{r}_{{\\rm{e}}}={0.86}_{-0.14}^{+0.19}\\;\\mathrm{kpc}</script></span></span>. The right-hand panel of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f8\">8</a> shows the precise <em>r</em><sub>e</sub> measurement of Muzzin et al. (2016, in preparation) as a function of the stellar mass. Over-plotted for comparison are a local, and high-redshift sample. Like the high-redshift sample, our object falls below the local size-mass relation (Shen et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib48\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib48\">2003</a>). We confirm, with a high degree of precision, that this galaxy is compact, which is consistent with what is seen for quiescent galaxies at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn197.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 2</script></span></span> (e.g., Daddi et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib20\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib20\">2005</a>; Trujillo et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib56\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib56\">2006</a>; Zirm et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib77\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib77\">2007</a>; van Dokkum et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib66\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib66\">2008</a>; Szomoru et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib52\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib52\">2012</a>).</p><p>Spectroscopy also allows for a kinematic determination of the mass. The measurement of a dynamical mass is important, as it provides a direct, kinematic method of probing the total matter content of a galaxy, without the uncertainties and prior assumptions associated with parameters such as distance measurement, IMF, and dust content (i.e Conroy et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib19\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib19\">2009</a> places the uncertainty associated with stellar mass estimates to be <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn198.gif\" alt=\"$0.6\\;\\mathrm{dex}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">0.6\\;\\mathrm{dex}</script></span></span> at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn199.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 2</script></span></span>). With the dynamical mass we are able to place a strict upper limit on the baryonic contribution to the total mass of the galaxy. In Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f9\">9</a> we compare the two measurements, and find the stellar and dynamical masses to be consistent with each other, although our results suggest either a low dark matter fraction in the inner kpc of the galaxy, where the bulk of the light is found, or perhaps that the stellar mass content is overestimated within the parameters discussed by Conroy et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib19\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib19\">2009</a>; such as assumptions about the IMF, dust content). However, Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f6\">6</a> shows, via the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn200.gif\" alt=\"$H{\\delta }_{A}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">H{\\delta }_{A}</script></span></span> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn201.gif\" alt=\"${D}_{n}4000$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{D}_{n}4000</script></span></span> indices, a model independent estimation of the age of this object. This result implies consistency in the model choice.</p><p>With a kinematic determination of the mass, and accurately measured structural parameters (<em>r</em><sub>e</sub>, and the S\u00e9rsic index <em>n</em>), we are able to place COSMOS\u00a00050+4901 on the MFP (Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f11\">11</a>). It is well established that local, quiescent galaxies fall on a FP described by surface brightness, size and stellar velocity dispersion (Djorgovski &amp; Davis <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib22\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib22\">1987</a>; Dressler et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib24\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib24\">1987</a>), which is tilted with respect to the prediction from virial equilibrium. This tilt does not evolve significantly, but there is an offset in the plane which becomes larger toward higher redshifts (e.g., van Dokkum &amp; Franx <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib64\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib64\">1996</a>; van Dokkum et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib65\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib65\">1998</a>; Treu et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib55\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib55\">1999</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib54\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib54\">2001</a>) as a result of the luminosity evolution of these galaxies with cosmic time. When replacing the surface brightness with stellar mass density (i.e., the MFP), Bezanson et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib6\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib6\">2013</a>) found that this offset does not evolve significantly and these galaxies fall on the same MFP out to <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn202.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 2</script></span></span>. In Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f11\">11</a> we compare the object in this study to the highest redshift galaxies available with a velocity dispersion measurement. We show that out to <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn203.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 3$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 3</script></span></span> quiescent galaxies fall on the same MFP, and that little evolution takes place between <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn204.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 3$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 3</script></span></span> and the present day.</p><p>A dynamical mass additionally enables the investigation of dark-matter content in the central regions of this galaxy. In Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f10\">10</a>, we have plotted the total-to-stellar mass ratio as a function of redshift, which shows evidence of a trend to decreasing values. However this trend is not statistically significant, as the uncertainties on the dynamical mass at high-<em>z</em> are large. More spectra of these types of objects are required to make a statistically significant claim. If this ratio is low, it is what is expected in the case of a gas-rich, major merger (Robertson et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib45\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib45\">2006</a>; Hopkins et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib28\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib28\">2009</a>), which implies that this galaxy could represent the first generation of quiescent galaxies in the hierarchical merging scenario (White &amp; Rees <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib73\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib73\">1978</a>), making this redshift epoch an exciting prospect for study.</p><p>This case study stands as a proof of concept of the utility of lensed, red galaxies in studying the population of passive galaxies down to lower masses as well as to higher redshifts. This paper also illustrates that few rest-frame optical spectra of quiescent galaxies exist beyond <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn205.gif\" alt=\"$z\\gt 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\gt 2</script></span></span>, and even fewer of galaxies at intermediate mass. We stress the need for further spectra of passive galaxies at higher-redshift, as well as to lower masses, as this parameter space is still under-explored.</p></div> <div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>This research has made use of NASA's Astrophysics Data System. The authors also wish to thank the anonymous referee who's suggestions improved the presentation, and overall clarity of this paper.</p></div></div><!-- End article full text -->\n<!-- Start Footnotes ta2\">\n                <!-- Start Content nav and Back to top link -->\n<aside class=\"content-nav show-w-js\">\n\t<ul class=\"content-nav-ul wd-content-nav\">\n\t</ul>\n\t<a data-footer-backtotop By continuing to use this site you agree to our use of cookies.</small></li>\n                    </ul>\n                </div>\n            </nav>\n            </div>\n        </div> <!-- end wrapper -->\n    </div> <!-- end iopp-footer -->\n</footer>\n<!-- Footer tile ends -->\n<script>\n  var imgBase = \"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img\";\n  /*  Cutting the mustard - http://responsivenews.co.uk/post/18948466399/cutting-the-mustard */\n\n  /* This is the original if statement, from the link above. I have amended it to turn of JS on all IE browsers less than 10.\n\tThis is due to a function in the iop.jquery.toolbar.js line 35/36. Uses .remove which is not native js supported in IE9 or lower */\n  /* if('querySelector' in document \n\t&& 'localStorage' in window\n\t&& 'addEventListener' in window) { */\n\n  /* This is the updated selector, taken from: https://justmarkup.com/log/2015/02/26/cut-the-mustard-revisited/ */\n\tif('visibilityState' in document) {\n\n\t/*! loadJS: load a JS file asynchronously. [c]2014 @scottjehl, Filament Group, Inc. (Based on http://goo.gl/REQGQ by Paul Irish).. Licensed MIT */\n\tfunction loadJS( src, cb ){\n\t  \"use strict\";\n\t  var ref = window.document.getElementsByTagName( \"script\" )[ 0 ];\n\t  var script = window.document.createElement( \"script\" );\n\t  script.src = src;\n\t  script.async = true;\n\t  ref.parentNode.insertBefore( script, ref );\n\t  if (cb && typeof(cb) === \"function\") {\n\t\tscript.onload = cb;\n\t  }\n\t  return script;\n\t}\n\n\tloadJS( \"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/js/scripts.min.js\" );\n\n  }\n</script>\n\n<script type=\"text/javascript\">window.NREUM||(NREUM={});NREUM.info={\"errorBeacon\":\"bam-cell.nr-data.net\",\"licenseKey\":\"b2bfaae1b6\",\"agent\":\"\",\"beacon\":\"bam-cell.nr-data.net\",\"applicationTime\":680,\"applicationID\":\"723879338\",\"transactionName\":\"NAAHMUBVCENSABFZXg1KLzZiGzF1cU4sfndMDxYVQRsFX14OCl4eDwQcCkdASFpAEw==\",\"queueTime\":0}</script></body>\n</html>", "Status": "Complete", "Action": "Scanned all subtables", "Table captions or footers": {"Overview": ">In addition to the stellar population parameters fit with FAST, we measured the Lick index <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn110.gif\" alt=\"$H{\\delta }_{A}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">H{\\delta }_{A}</script></span></span> (Worthey &amp; Ottaviani <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib75\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib75\">1997</a>) and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn111.gif\" alt=\"${D}_{n}(4000)$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{D}_{n}(4000)</script></span></span> (Balogh et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib2\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib2\">1999</a>) break, which are features shown to be sensitive to age (Kauffmann et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj522770bib30\" id=\"fnref-apj522770bib30\">2003</a>). With an <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn112.gif\" alt=\"$H{\\delta }_{A}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">H{\\delta }_{A}</script></span></span> measurement from our spectrum, as well as coverage of the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn113.gif\" alt=\"$4000\\;\\mathring{\\rm A} $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">4000\\;\\mathring{\\rm A}</script></span></span> break (as seen by the blue horizontal bars in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f5\">5</a>), we are able to independently verify our model age determination. This independent age verification from the absorption features is important because of inherent degeneracies in fitting the SED. In Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj522770f6\">6</a>, we have plotted <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn114.gif\" alt=\"$H{\\delta }_{A}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">H{\\delta }_{A}</script></span></span> as a function of the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/819/1/74/Full/apj522770ieqn115.gif\" alt=\"${D}_{n}(4000)$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{D}_{n}(4000)</script></span></span> of our object, as well as a random sample of SDSS galaxies which contain both star-forming and quiescent galaxies."}, "Pandas format": {"Table 2": {"Status": "Complete", "Action": "Processed via pandas", "Inspection": {"Notes": {"Skip cause table not important": "", "Message on table quality": "Manually extract z"}}}}}}, "Tables status": "Complete", "Inspection status": "Complete"}
